It's clean, safe and quite warm especially everytime I back after walking around Tokyo to feel the cold autumn :) I really missed this place and its neighbourhood..Lawson, Tomod's..(I'm crying now! hahah) I hope I can comeback to Tokyo again and stay at this hotel..again. Greets from Indonesia :)

My bf and i enjoy our stay here.The location was quite good with many restaurants and eateries nearby.The station is about 5 mins walk way which straight bring u direct to shinjuku.If u like park highly recommend yoyogi park .It took abt 30mins walking distance from hotel.fr yoyogi park it took abt 30 mins to Shibuya.The room is small but clean and with bathroom .Staff are friendly and can speak English as well.Overall we can say tat we would come back and stay in Sakura hotel .

Room is small for a family of four. However the amenties and the nearby food options are good. But Hotel staff were really friendly and helpful, helping with our taxi reservation and parcel service at the nearby Japan Post branch.

We stayed at Sakura Hotel - Hatagaya for 3 nights last June, 2017. It's a very nice, quiet & secured place, very clean and accommodating staff. There is also an area in the hotel (w/cctv camera) wherein you can leave your baggage after you check out just in case you still would like to go around for sightseeing or shopping.

Our experience in Sakura Hatagaya hotel was just wonderful!! The workers there are very friendly, there is a unique social atmophere focused on making tourist to feel at home, where different events take place for free. Moreover, the price/quality is one of the best ones of Tokyo. From Vero4travel we trully recommend you to go to this hotel in order to enjoy your stay in hotel. Thank you Sakura Hotel for making our trip so comfortable and unforgettable!!!

Great room, great staff, and really close to transit and amenities. I was here for a business trip and the room was perfect for me and my needs. The cafe downstairs was convenient and served great food.

I liked this Hotel. Very nice staff, that were patient with my restricted knowledge of Japanese (they luckily spoke English)- they offered cool coupons and the cafe food Array was pretty good. - The rooms are a bit small, but most Japanese Hotels are, I think I am too used to European sizes.

I’ve stayed here for a week or longer, twice a year, for many years, and will continue returning in the future. The staff is very helpful, especially for newcomers to Tokyo.There is a 24-hour restaurant in the lobby, and many restaurants in the area. There is an ATMin the Post Office next door, and a pharmacy across the street. The train station is a few minutes walk, with trains going to Shinjuku, two stops away.

Great place to stay with private bathrooms, heaters. The room is a little small, due to the bed being so big so it would be better to get the japanese tatami rooms. To maximize space. It offers breakfast also

Location is the key value, 3 minutes to hatagaya station, many local & western food nearby. Room is just okay w/ nice wifi, and the staffs are really helpfull and friendly, fluent in English & Mandarin.

-Great location being a stone's throw from Hatagaya Station. Shinjuku and just 2 stops (2-3 minutes) away.-Friendly and helpful staff.-Clean and decently-sized (for Tokyo) rooms.-Multiple convenient stores nearby-Overall one of the best hotels in terms of value for money.

I love everything about this hotel, the staffs, the provided services like cafe, laundries and maps, the neighborhood area near to train station and mart. All are wonderful except for the small size of room which is hard to move around. So most of the time we eat, pray, and rest, technically on the bed! But i would definitely choose to stay here again and improvise where i could, for instance eat at the cafe and pray in the musolla provided.

very good hotel, strategic location, reasonable price. the receptionist officer who is friendly and good at english and indonesian. there is musholah for moslem. clean rooms and available washing machine.

Small cozy room, with great AC and friendly staff. The room had a mini fridge and free Wi-Fi. The house keeping was great everyday. The TV wasn't HiDef and had no HDMI port though. Located close to the Hatagaya station. They also let you use an umbrella for free for the day when it rains.

If you visit Tokio you walk a lot because it's has a lot of places to discover and at the end of the day you feel tired. However, When I arrived at Sakura Hotel I feel at home because I could take a bath in a clean tub with refreshing towels so I was reader for the following day.

This was my second time staying at Sakura Hostel Hatagaya. It is a great location for those that want to visit Shinjuku, Shibuya, Harajuku, etc. The metro is just a five minute walk, rooms are small but comfortable and staff is great.

The hotel is close to Hatagaya station, our room in the Hotel is relatively ok, just windy, the breeze enters from the gap at bottom of the door. The breakfast was to simple if compare to the rate of the hotel

The room, bathroom and elevator is really small. The staffs are friendly with fluent English. Breakfast is just bread, margerine, jam and vege soup. Near convenience store and a local train/subway. But be aware it does not cover a subway pass even if google map said you should stay in the same train you need to get off at Shinjuku station to buy a ticket unless you have ICOCA.

Recommended to all muslim visitor .With the comfortable prayer room , clean toilet and very helpful front desk staff.Close to subway Hatagaya and 24hour family mart.Sure will be back someday hopefully during olympic tokyo.

It was quiet hotel and our room is good. When we had a trouble using computer, the staff helped us a lot. We are really appreciate it.We hope to stay here again next time we visit Tokyo and also recommend it to our friends.

Would recommend this hotel to anyone travelling to Japan!! Rooms and neat and clean a bit small but overall perfect!! Close to train station! Staff are amazing and very attentive!! Yasuyuki was a great help in helping me find locations and directions, calling doctors for me when i was sick!! Wifi is a bit bad but it still worked!!! When i travel back to japan i will be staying here again

This is my first time visiting Japan. The staff is helpful, friendly, and speak English well. They helped me make reservations and directions. The hotel is conveniently located next to the Hatagaya station, which is just 2 stops from Shinjuku station. There are restaurants, a convenience store (Family Mart) and a bakery (Les Rapas) nearby as well. The station and restaurants are literally around the corner (1-2 min walk). There is also a Mosque 15 min walk away from the hotel.The hotel has a 24-hour cafe and has washer/dryer available that is affordable to use.For Muslims visiting Tokyo, I'd recommend looking into this hotel. Japan is not familiar about Muslims. The staff here have a better understanding and might be able to help with reservations at some Muslim restaurants. There is also a small prayer room in the first floor. Other than this hotel, I have stayed at another hotel in Japan as well (APA Hotel in Shinjuku). The other hotel was a bit more expensive than Sakura, however, the rooms at both hotels were smaller compared to hotels I've stayed in in other countries. In terms of facilities, Sakura Hotel -Hatagaya is a budget friendly hotel. So, do not expect a fancy hotel. At the same time, Sakura Hotel provides a great place to stay for those on a budget and need the room for resting and showering while exploring Tokyo.At the hotel I stayed in their double and deluxe double room. If you are by yourself then the double room will be sufficient unless you have a lot of luggage. The deluxe double is good for three people who do not have a lot of luggage (a carry on and personal bag each is fine).Overall, for the price this is an excellent hotel to stay in. I'd give it 5 stars if the dryer at the hotel dried the clothes better (but that's a very minor thing)

Please don't go in this hotel there are very unprofessional immature, young workers at the front desk i book this hotel for 8 days after two days i cancel my stay and pay the cancellation fee about 43 $ i think this place is family hotel that wy there act like that if you want to enjoy your trip in Tokyo don't go there please .

First of all we booked and payed in advance for a standard twin room its was raining and i am with my 1 year old and my 17 year old son. They messed up the room saying they were fully booked and this lady rolled her eyes at me like im the one who messed it up then put us in a futon room that is dirty used towels all around the place and all futons and blankets are used in short they put us in an uncleaned room i rush to them to say they gave us a dirty room and this guy wanted to check it toake sure and there he just said so sorry we will just look for another room. Still ive been polite and waited took my kids out of the room for we dont know who used the room and i have a 1 year old baby with me.. then they put us in a room which is really stinky.. fifth floor room 503.. my 17 year old just wanted to rest for we had a very long travel from aomori and my baby is tired too we settled on that stinky room.. i dont know why everytime they sees us they glare stare roll their eyes and everything. Is it just because they are just rude or prejudice or i dont know. It was unpleasant and really disappointing.. this is not a hotel bad service rude people stinky and dirty rooms. I will never recommend this specially if you are with kids. Sorry but they need to teach their staffs some manners.

Room is small but I think it has been a standard Japanese room. This has been our 2nd hotel, one is at Nagoya during our stay in Japan. I got a standard non-smoking room. I hate it coz the rooms here are not soundproof. I can actually hear the sound of the tv from the other room. Sometimes there is a water cut-off but didn’t report to management since it just resumes in a couple of minutes. Free breakfast includes unli bread, jam, soup, tea, and coffee. Love that it is near to convenient store and restaurants. But overall, I will not recommend this to people who prioritize comfort over budget.

* Good Hotel, helpful staff, service are good.* Nearest public transport train keio line hatagaya.* Convenience store as Family Mart.* this hotel have own Cafe.* Food cheap, juice is delicious.* thank you so much.

It is a good hotel when you arrive to tokyo form paris.You can synchronize before to travel in JAPANThe Room is not Big.But the hotel is near shinjuku.The Personne of Hotel said "Good Honey Moon" it is a good point

We were a group of 14 pax and we got 1 triple room, 3 twin rooms and 1 corner double room. We stayed at Sakura Hotel Hatagaya for 4 nights. This was our second Sakura Hotel in Tokyo, we stayed at Sakura Hotel Jimbocho 3 years ago. I liked SHH better because it exceeded all my expectations. The corner double room was equipped with 1 double bed and 1 sofa bed, mini-refrigerator, slippers, bathrobe, and TV (Japanese channels only). The room was small (Japanese standards) but had enough space for our luggage. It also has its own toilet and bathroom, complete with the usual Shampoo, Conditioner, and Bath Gel (which I loooove). Towels were available, as well as toothbrush. The hotel has its own café where you could avail their breakfast buffet of toast and jam for 350yen (with coffee or tea). Front desk was so accommodating and helpful. The real reason you should book at this hotel is its LOCATION. Very conveniently located just a few meters from the Hatagaya Subway Station. This subway station has an elevator that takes you to the street, so very convenient for you and your luggage. Hatagaya Station is just 3 stops away from Shinjuku Station. There were a lot of restaurants around the hotel as well as a Family Mart. Stop searching for another hotel in Tokyo, do yourself a favor and book Sakura Hotel Hatagaya NOW! Real value for your money.

we booked 2 types of rooms : single and triple rooms. My single room was great however there was no cupboard/kettle... bt it was not a must in my case as i prefer to hav drinks at the lobby. The triple room was more compact and difficult to move around tho ... oh ya the beds! It was sooo hard on the body as my dad says u can feel the metal popping out! So all he cld do was put another layer of material on top of it Overall it was a good stay as the location n surroundings was lively and easy to shop hence close to the train station

Sakura Hotel Hatagaya should not be branded as a "hotel" as it is basically a hostel. I will be as fair and honest in this review. The good news is the "hotel" provides daily cleaning service from 10 am to 2 pm. So you don't have to worry about cleanliness in that sense. It is also a 5-min walk from Keio New Line's Hatagaya Station. There are many affordable food choices near the "hotel" such as Sukiya and Origin Dining. Family Mart is also near the "hotel". However, there are some cons staying in this "hotel". I don't consider this a hotel because the set-up is too hostel-like. The lift is slow and old. The rooms are really tiny. It is impossible to put two luggage in the same room. You will have to stuff one of the luggage under your bed. I could barely open the room door without hitting my luggage. The rooms are also not soundproof. I could basically hear what the guests in the other room were talking from my room.  Another thing that really made my stay kind of uncomfortable was the attitude by the staff. I arrived in the morning and approached the staff politely to let her know that I am here. While I was busy searching for my passport (because I don't know the procedures for check-in at that point), the staff (a woman) said that check-in was after 3pm in a really rude tone. She even glared and stared at me. Throughout the rest of my stay, whenever I see her, I caught her rolling my eyes at me or just glaring at me. On the day I checked out, I asked another staff (a man) politely if they had the airport bus service from Shinjuku Bus terminal to the airport. However, he looked very frustrated and said no. I asked if there was a way to check the timetable and he looked very unhappy and said to check the website for details. When I was leaving the hotel, the staff glared at stared at me. I wonder if glaring at guests is a service that they think is acceptable to guests Apart from these two staff members, the rest of the staff, including the cleaning crew is polite and friendly. Please be wary even if they claim that Shinjuku is just two stops away from Hatagaya. Yes, it is true that Shinjuku is just two stops away from Hatagaya. However, you always need to take the Keio New Line from Shinjuku only. This makes travelling very inconvenient especially if you buy the one-day or three-day Tokyo metro pass. This is because the Keio New Line is not covered under the metro pass. This means that your trip from Shinjuku to Hatagaya for a one-way trip is about 125 yen - which also means additional transport cost. At Shinjuku Station, it is advisable to take the Odeo Line or the Shinjuku (green) line (from wherever you are coming from) if you want to take the Keio New Line. I will never come back to stay here because the bad service really turn me off.

We arrived at 1.30 in the morning and were quickly suprised with the Indonesian-speaking front office staff who turned out to have lived in Jakarta for two years. Bedroom was understandably small, breakfast was simple -breads, clear soup, coffee and tea-, coin laundry service and a vending machine (of course!) on the fifth floor which I visited very often, well traveling with young kids, seeing a laundry machine is like gold to me. Very close to Hatagaya station, convenience stores just across the street, bakery and McDonald's within five minutes walk, and a lovely quiet neighborhood if you walk a little further down the road.

Good value for money in expensive Tokyo. small room, good location. if you want bigger room in good location have to pay more: - Clean rooms-Well equipped (toothbrush, towels, slippers, robes, fridge, tv etc)-Simple breakfast included (coffee & toast)-Very close to train station (Hatagaya- Keio new line)- good location (2 train stations from Shinjuku) - hot shower - aircon/heater - comfortable bed - quiet - 24 hour cafe, restaurants and family mart than 5 minutes walk away - very nice, safe area: have a walk around Hatagaya streets! - very small room and bathroomRecommended

The hotel is best for location, as it takes only around 2-3 minutes’ walk to the nearest station, Hatagaya subway station. This is awesome for visitors to take transportation to travel. Besides, there is a post office on the right of the hotel, which makes postcards posting much convenient. Finally, there is a healthcare store with some food and drinks available for sale. I do not have to worry about forgetting to bring any healthcare products next time when I stay in this hotel. I also can buy some food or drinks very easily. If you were on business trip, this hotel is recommended in terms of convenient transportation. The one that makes me mad the most is the tap water in the restroom. The supply of cold water is unstable. It could happen to suspend temporarily. And after some time, the cold-water supply resumes. This is terrible if I had put the soap on the skin and the cold water were suspended. What was weird is that there are no one to fix it even there is daily room cleaning service. I cannot rate higher than zero in a scale of ten for this. Another thing that dissatisfied me so much was that you must check out so early, that is, at 10:00 hrs (Tokyo time). Just imagine if you woke up late after a day of content activities, you need to pay 1,000 YEN for one additional hour that you check out after 10:00 hrs. To avoid additional charges, I tried my best to check out before 10 am. Last but not the least, do not expect much about the breakfast at hotel. It is just bread and coffee.

We stayed for two weeks and we really had a comfortable stay. The hotel room is a little too small but it's nice and neat. Our accommodation comes with free breakfast ,but only a few choices of food . Only the soup is variable but it's okay it's healthy and delicious . Location is very accessible to anywhere . Only 1a station away from Shinjuku station . One of the largest station . This hotel is best recommended for foreign tourist . Hotel staff is good in English . I noticed, along with me, mostly guests are foreigners came form different country .

The staffs are friendly, nice, helpful and spoke English. Rooms are small (especially the toilet) and toilet have some weird odour (not sure other rooms had the same problem). Strategic location where short walking distance to Subway train station. Surrounded by 24 hours mart and restaurant. Prices are quite reasonable compared to other hotels.

Feels a bit like a hostel in part. Very central - close to pretty much everything you could need. The staff are lovely & fluent in English, & incredibly helpful. The rooms are very small & basic, & the breakfasts mainly consist of bread & coffee, but there are plenty of places to go for more 'exciting' meals.

The hotel is simple and the rooms are very small, but it is very comfortable, quiet, clean, and the staff is very kind. It is close to a supermarket, restaurants and, most importantly, it is two blocks from Hatagaya Station (Keio New Line). Next to the reception desk there is a café where breakfast is served and where guests can order meals and snacks.

This hotel had very nice staff, a simple breakfast which helped sustain us till we got further afield, and tidy, clean rooms. Very close to Hatagaya station south exit (100m or so). No toothpaste was supplied though so helps if you bring your own (shampoo and shower gel were).

Simple room but clean and well located. Staff is very helpful. Breakfast very simple but helps to spend the day. Room is small but in the Japanese standard. Shared bathroom. Calm and organized. I recommend for low budget

Home to backpackers passing through as well as expats with short-term contracts (teaching, translation, and who knows?) this is a very convenient location, proximate to Hatagaya subway station. The price is certainly affordable, the front desk staff are both a joy and also a treasure trove of useful information (and all have very competent English). This is very 'homely' and after a while I started feeling protective of the location ~ which is a positive sign signaling my comfort with the services. I would return here in a heartbeat .... And recommend you consider this if you're at all adventurous.

I stayed for two weeks in this hotel and had a nice time here. Staff was friendly and the room was okay. The restaurant is very conveniant. The best part, in my opinion, was the location. If you are not scared of walking a bit, you can reach Shinjuku, Shibuya and Harajuku in 40 minutes. Almost never used public transports. There are stores and restaurants around the hotel in case you want to eat something or need anything. Recommanded.

great staff, room was very clean, just enough space for me (i only travel with a backpack and I am a small guy). location isnt bad, right by the subway, but its not the main subway line, so you have to take it to get to whatever main train line you want but no big deal because it is only 1 stop from shibuya station. downstairs cafe was great, great homey feeling, food and beer 24 7 and wifi worked great in the cafe so thats where i spend most of my time when in the hotel. mostly people using there laptops with headphones so pretty heard to talk to people if you want to meet people. japan is an expensive country in general but you really cant beat it for the price. laundry on site as well. would stay again

Sakura Hotel Hatagaya has different kinds of room. Most rooms are western style, but recently the opened a couple of Japanese style rooms. The beds are good. You can adjust the room temperature to your liking. The staff is friendly and helpful. The breakfast is not big. There are many restaurants and a 24-hour open big food-store close to the hotel.

As long as your visit is brief & intended for the city, not the stay, you'll like the value of this budget hotel. Very friendly & helpful staff. Nothing special breakfast, just toast & coffee but their beer & curry selection are impressive. It's a little loud but we were happy to save money & see Tokyo from here. Convenient location, access to the metro & great advise. Solid place to stay but not for a week or so, the nuisances would grow tiresome. Very clean! Enjoy,

We stayed here for 5 nights in December 2016. The rooms were well-appointed (small as you would expect for this price in Tokyo) and comfortable. The location is two stops off the main shinjuku line, so expect to spend a fair bit of time transitting through there to get around. Great base to explore Tokyo.

Stayed here for 3 night. Ideally located near Hatagaya station, only 3 min. walking. The station have a lift from the train platform to the ticket office area and another lift from the ticket office area to the the street level. So it is very convenient for people with suitcases All the staffs are very helpful and they can speak verry good english which is rare for this type of a hotel in Japan.The area is very quiet but there are 2 convenience store, places to eat and a bakery nearby.The interior is a bit outdated but the room facility is quite complete except that they don't provide electric kettle, but you can borrow from the front officers for free.The hotel cafe itself open for 24 hour and They serve halal menu but with a very limited choice.Overall it's a nice place to stay!

Little clean room.the breakfast was nothing special. The stuff was very friendly. In the night it is loud because the windows are not very well isolated. Just said. Its ok for one night. You get what you pay for :).

During my visit to Japan this time, I went alone by myself and for solo traveller, i think the room is good enough to just sleep. You don't want to waste your time all day at the hotel. The hotel is in the quiet area, so you won't get distract by noise. And the location is even best, 2mins to convenient store and less than 5mins to the train station

Chose this hotel based on the price and the location. Only a 2 min walk from Hatagaya station, which is three stops or so from Shinjuku Station. Lots of eateries and convenience stores nearby the hotel. The staff spoke decent English and were very accommodating. Rooms are small and a bit dated (probably haven't been upgraded since the late 80's), but OK for å shorter period of time. Free wifi and fridge in the room was a huge plus!

After been travelling Japan for 2 weeks on homestays i was keen to return the last night to Tokyo before my long flight in a hotel. The place is very small as can be expected for this "low" price, but still pricey for this quality, compare to USA and Europa, but so is everything in Japan. I did not expect much, so did not really get dissapointed. All was well cleaned when i arrived, but after I used the sink, an incredible smell of urine took over the bathroom. Everytime i washed my hands of shower, this smell will act up from the drains. Really nasty. Did not complain as it was just one night and i just wanted to rest. Maybe they would have moved me, maybe not. Staff was very friendly.

The place is only about 5 minutes walk from hatagaya subway station (not covered by jr pass)I booked a room for 4 persons and there was only small space for baggage. (Not enough for 4 baggages)The wifi connection is good There is private bathroom and toilet which are separated. But AC in our room was not working at that time. And it was 11 degrees at night and we were freezing in our room. The breakfast is good as well. Bread and soup with milk. This hotel allowed us to keep our baggages at the check out time without any fee There are family mart and small restaurants near this hotel. And the price for the meal (lunch/dinner) is really cheap

Hotel was very decent. It was clean and staff were helpful and efficient. We had a problem with the air conditioning which kept us up one night, but it was quickly sorted out the next day. Location was good too. Would recommend for families as well as couples.

This is a good budget option in Tokyo. The room was small, but very clean. Hatagaya is only a couple of stops on the Keio New Line from Shinjuku station, so the location was convenient. From the station, take the south exit, go up the stairs, turn right at street level to the end of the block, then turn right again and the hotel is a few yards away on the right. The staff is extremely friendly and welcoming. The breakfast is nothing fancy ... it's basically toast, jam and a different kind of soup broth every morning, but you can take as much as you want, and you don't have to get up super early. They also sell slightly discounted metro passes at the hotel, good for one day, two days, and several other options, which was great. The passes aren't good on the JR lines, or even the Keio New Line that the hotel is on, but that will only set you back around 160 yen from Shinjuku. I didn't have any problems with the wifi, though I wasn't ever in the hotel between 9am and midnight. I believe I saw self-service washing machines on one floor, though I did not use them since it was the first stop on my vacation.

I've been to Japan thrice in the past two years and I know what to expect from the hotel room size. This one tops it all when it comes to tiniest category. In my estimate, the twin occupancy room that I got is not bigger than 8 sq. meters. This is the only hotel, so far, that I've gone through whose water closet doesn't have a bidet. The following is my review summary:Upside:1. The housekeeping cleans the room efficiently.2. There is a free wi-fi inside the room.3. There is a small fridge inside the room. If it is a plus, a bathrobe is also provided,4. Breakfast, in the form of bread and fruit jam, is free.5. The hotel is located near restaurants and convenience stores.6. As a trademark Japanese hotel, the rooms are clean.6. The room rates are quite reasonable by Japanese standard (or the same rate as a large 4-star hotel room in Manila)Downside.1. The rooms are so small that one can hardly stand beside the bed, much less,have an adequate breathing space.2. The bathtub is likewise too size-challenged that one is compelled not to move move his arms sidewards lest he bumps the wall or the shower curtain. Shampoo, body wash, toothbrush, a face and bath towels are provided (do not expect other standard hotel toiletries like shaver, lotion, comb, cotton buds)3. The TV has no English channel, hence, if you are not a Japanese, do not bother turning it on.4. There is no complimentary coffee or tea. Neither there is a water kettle.5. The air-conditioning systems hums rather noisily.6. The water closet has no bidet,much more automatic bidet, that I've grown accustomed to in other Japanese hotels.7.There is practically no hotel lobby to hold you while you are waiting (you have to stand up on the line during check-in).8. Like its room, the elevator is so small it can only hold 4 persons.9. Bed mattress is a bit hard and pillows are undersized.10,. Buffet breakfast comes in the form of bread and three types of fruit jams and a butter, with soup. Do not expect anything new in the breakfast for any succeeding day.

Just a 2 minute walk from Hatagaya Station (take the south exit, up the stairs past McDonalds) there is an elevator in the station which makes it easier with heavy luggage. Quite a few restaurants and a family mart next to the hotel.Staff were very friendly and helpful and spoke very good English. Room was small as expected in Tokyo, but for the price I was pleasantly surprised. The room matched my needs perfectly (single room) has a comfortable bed, AC which works well (although you may need to turn off the timer unless you want it to switch off after 30 mins or so). Room has a desk and enough space to store luggage without falling over it.  ou toast yourself, with coffee and tea. Did the job and was a bonus considering the price of the room. Hatagaya Station is only two stops from Shinjuku making it very convenient. Highly recommend this hotel, I'm sure I'll be back.

Easy access from airport,located near Hatagaya Station. It has convenience stores, restaurants nearby.Offers decent choice of a light breakfast .Wifi needs improvement.Corner rooms are larger.Good service from Front Desk staff especially Koudai Matsushita.

Awesome staff! The room is just right since I travelled with my mom alone. Breakfast is very light because it consists of coffee, bread and soup. If you really want to eat heavy, there are nearby restaurants and fast foods in the neighborhood. There are also drugstores and convenience stores near the hotel so its bery convenient. In addition, its just less than 5 minute walk from the train station. One thing I can recommend is not to take the train from airport to hotel if you're carrying heavy luggages because its really hard to commute. You'll have to carry your luggages up and downstairs which is kind of hassle. Going back to the airport, we took a cab from the hotel to the bus limousine station then rode from there to the airport! Its very convenient and cheaper than riding the cab all the way!

Four of us traveled to Tokyo and found this place to stay for our trip. We stayed for 8 days and 7 nights. Easy to find and close to Hatagaya Station. 3 convenience stores all within walking distance - 7-eleven, Lawson, Family mart. Ample of food place to have lunch or dinner. Not to mention a post office nearby to post your postcards and a pharmacy outlet - Tomod's within a minute of walk to do your cosmetic shopping. We had a room with 2 single beds and 1 queen size bed. Room is small but standard for Japan. Room service is good. Bed made and towels changed daily. There's also self service laundry facility available for reasonable cost. Will choose to stay there again if I were to visit Tokyo again.

Small room but doesnt matter, too much to see in Tokyo to worry about running around a hotel room... Very comfy from day one, almost felt like home. Staff are nice and speak excellent english. Location is great, right around the corner from Hatagaya Station and two min to Shinjuku. Not to mention plenty of places to eat in the area if you feel like staying in a night. Spent 7 nights here and each one was great.

I stayed at the Sakura Hotel for a few days early July. I booked it knowing it wouldn't be a 5 star resort. The hotel is located in Hatagaya, very close to the station. I had no issue getting there from Narita airport. The location is great for first time visitors to Tokyo and very close to Shinjuku, Harajuku and other metro lines. The rooms are very small and so is the bathroom but it was a nice change, The bed was comfortable, aircon worked great and it was a comfortable stay. The staff are very very helpful and had no problem with helping me get to tourist spots. The breakfast is toast, pastry, with a spread of jam or butter as an option. Wifi worked great in the canteen area however, was useless in the rooms. This place has a hostel vibe to it but also a hotel. Personally i would return if i was going back to Tokyo alone as it is cheap, comfortable and very close to everything.

The Hotel is centrally located close to the station very close to the transportation hug of Shinjuku station in a quite part of town .Good place to move around the city .Rooms are small barely managed to get my 27 " suitcase in bathroom for Japan standard very old style and small .Being on business wifi sucks was all set to change hotels ,night time can never get wifi in the rooms .Stayed 10days wanted a later check out by 1 hour they were charging me like full day room rate so checked out and moved to another hotel whose price was lower and better

We were a little worried about our booking at this hotel for the end of our trip. Coming to Japan during Cherry Blossom season, finding a reasonably priced hotel was a challenge. This hotel seemed a bit too-good-to-be-true with a rate at only just over $100/night, however we had read numerous good reviews and were hopeful. What we found was just what the reviews has promised: a bright, lively lobby staffed by young, multilingual staff and basic rooms. The Sakura feels more like a hostel than a hotel, but it was welcoming and inexpensive. The clientele reflected that hostel feeling: a mix of guests from all over the world, young travellers and families. We had a corner room which was larger than the rooms we had stayed in in many business hotels. There was a fridge and desk space and a small bathroom (sink/toilet/shower). The wifi was spotty at times. The bedding and towels were pretty utilitarian and the decor was dated but the bed was comfortable. Location-wise the hotel also good. The neighbourhood around the hotel has lots of shops and small restaurants and is well worth exploring. In the end, we were happy with our stay and would return. This is not a hotel for those looking for luxury and style but is great if you are looking for a safe, comfortable place to lay your head.Some transit tips: The train to Shinjuku comes frequently and takes only a few minutes. Be warned however that the travel time within Shinjuku is almost laughably long. The Keio New Line seems to be located at a far flung corner of Shinjuku Station, well underground: transferring from other lines involves a lot of walking, stairs, escalators and some very poor signage. Easy once you've done it a few times, but quite confusing the first time. It is possible to walk to Shinjuku Station, but it is a long walk. We found we walked more often toward Yoyogi Park and the stations there -- using Google maps this was a pleasant walk through residential neighbourhoods and didn't feel long.

I would say once I got over the size of the bedrooms and having to live in a very small hotel room, (which is normal here) this hotel is very very convenient. I found it just a few minutes walk from Hatagaya station, a lovely restaurant (origin dining) which we were in 6 times, a 24 hour supermarket a few minutes further down the road. One really bad point on the hotel is that to gain access to the hotel you must walk through the smoking area where I must have smoked about 10 a day, not bad for a non smoker.

It was my first time staying in Tokyo and Sakura Hatagaya hotel turned out to be a fine choice. Very cheap hotel yet provides excellent room services, 24 hour cafe, mutilingual staff and close proximity to Lawson (convenience store), Family Mart, restaurants and Hatagaya Subway station which is 3 minutes to Shinjuku station. I can definately recommend this hotel, served me great as a single traveller, facilities were more then adequate, washing necessitiets such as soap, shampoo and toothbrushes are provided daily. Rooms have a mini fridge, tv and a desk as well as an inbuilt wall alarm clock. Overall, 10/10, will definately try and book this hotel again when I come back to Tokyo, would even like to thank the staff for their friendly service and kindness when I managed to lock myself out of my room! ^^

First time for our trip in Japan and it was a right choose for stay here. Hotel is just a few min from Hatagaya train station and it was 2 stations from Shinjuku station (130yen). It was very convenient to stay here, a bit small room but all is organize with facilities that you needed. Private bathroom with little bathtub and hot water. We stay in hotel just for sleep and relax so it was fine and quiet area many restaurants around this area also price is cheaper then business area plus minimart just in front. They do provide continental breakfast (buffet) it was good enough with daily fresh juice, fresh coffee, selection of tea, daily soup of the day etc. Free wifi all area was perfect. Perfect choose!

This hotel is by the hatagaya subway station. It is two stations from shinjuku station. The location is all local which makes it great. It is the only hotel in the area. It seems that besides the people staying in the station, it is all locals. There is a pedestrain walking path a block away and the yoyogi park is a great little run away. I got a morning run in from the hotel to yoyogi park which was a great way to see the little streets and all the local people doing their daily routine. The hotel is surrounded by many amenities so you don't need to travel far to get food or supplies. I stayed in the new japanese style housing which was coffee shop(japanese size) and now two units with japanese style bedding. It would be a very good size for two or three people. We had four people which was a little tight. It's a great quiet place to stay.

Had a great stay at Sakura Hotel Hatagaya, the staffs are really friendly and helpful! :) One tiny disappointment is that I can't seem to connect to the wifi from my room? But the connection is pretty strong if you are at the cafe. Overall, I had a great stay and would definitely be staying here the next time I visit Japan!

A hotel for business and tourist visitors. Good for families. Not a party hotel. Clever and helpful staff, providing good information about attractions and how to get there. Big internetcafè/breakfast area in the lobby, cafè open 24 hours. Good coffee. The internet (free wi-fi) is slow (overcrowded) during peak hours. PC with internet LAN connection for rent in the cafè, very affordable. All guest rooms have a fridge. Excellent food store 24 hour open, around the corner (Gourmet City). There is a good public bath close to the hotel. From Hatagaya station to entrance of Sakura Hotel Hatagaya is 200 steps.

Very polite staff, too miresarable breakfast (just bread, some butter and coffee), perfect location, reasonable price. Too close to all the central Tokyo sights. The rooms are clean but too small. Easy to find.

We enjoyed our stay at Sakura Hotel Hatagaya! The location is great, very close to the subway station, with many authentic restaurants and supermarkets around. The staff is very friendly and ready to help with any of your questions at any time of the day or even night.

Stayed here for about a month in the summer, solo travel. The room was very small but the hotel was very clean, the staff were very friendly (and all speak english), and the room had all the essentials it needs (air con, shower, TV, etc). The lobby is also very nice and has a good selection of beer, if that's what you're into. It was inexpensive and the staff were totally willing to help out with anything I needed in getting around Tokyo or finding places to go. Hatagaya is a lovely area, very close to Shinjuku, Harajuku, Shibuya etc, and the hotel is just around the corner from the station. There's a McDonalds around the corner too but there's also some great ramen bars, small restaurants, and Izakayas in the area so if you're a foreigner looking for a better Japanese experience like I was, then you're totally covered. Only negatives I personally had were the small rooms (which are inevitable if you're staying at a budget hotel in Tokyo) and the fact I was too tall for the shower (which isn't going to be an issue for anyone around 6 foot and under). My room was also right next to the laundry area, and I did once have an entire girls' sports team making a lot of noise outside of my room, but fortunately there's a 10pm-10am curfew in place for this exact reason. Generally, however, the hotel was pretty quiet, like Hatagaya in general. Most of the noise comes from the cicadas in the summer, and they seem to pipe down when night falls. Would strongly recommend, I've recommended it to all of my friends in Tokyo, and I'll definitely be coming back.

I stayed here to run the Tokyo Marathon because it was close to the start line, and though a bit of a splurge for a budget traveller, it was well worth the price. Very clean, quiet and staff who clearly love their job! They went out of their way to prepare a pre-race meal that met my dietary needs, all while hosting a well-attended special culinary event for other guests, and later checked in to see how my run had gone. The bathroom was a bit cramped, but being able to do laundry onsite was a bonus.

Very nice and simple hostal . Staff very helpful and polite. Don't expect too much from the room its basic but has everything you need . Clean above all which is the most important thing . One more thing !!! Double check your bannc movements cause it heapend to us to be twice charged for booking and 4 days after we left the hostal !!!

The hotel is very conveniently located at hatagaya station. MacDonald's nearby. 24hours 2-storey supermarket. Lots of eating places near the other traffic junction. 2 convenience stores nearby, family mart just right outside, and lawsons few mins walk up the street. Staff-wise, not a friendly bunch but efficient enough. Rooms are big. We took the triple bedroom and the beds were very comfy. Heater and tv worked well. Hv to ask the counter for a kettle and it wasnt working so had to exchange for another one. All in all, a good enough place for a long or short stay.

I stayed at Sakura Hotel for 6 nights. I had looked at reviews before booking so I was not surprised at the small room. I would recommend this hotel for a 2-3 night stay. For 6 nights the small room becomes quite difficult to live in but it still works as a clean room, nice bed and a decent sized bathroom. The staff were very nice and helpful. The breakfast was really nice, very simple toast and rolls with jams and tea. It would be great if they had some fruit as well.

First I will tell you the bad and then the good:The rooms are beyond small so make sure you only carry small luggage or it will block your ability to move let alone open your suitcase in your room.The cleanliness (we stayed in a family room the second night) was so so. Stains on the carpet,old blood stain on the linen,tired curtains and linen. Also we stayed in a non-smoking room but had to endure the reek of smoke which made it hard to breathe.(someone was smoking on our floor).Dining cutlery and trays were not clean...Very basic breakfast of sweet rolls,jam,juice and coffee.The good,the staff spoke excellent english and were extremely helpful and polite.The location was very interesting with convenient supermarkets,shops,chemists,restaurants and subway within walking distance.We did not find it particularly cheap and stayed at better hotels for better prices but if you can grab a sale we would stay here again as it is so convenient and the staff.(they also let us store luggage in a so so secure area near front desk for free which was really good).Recommend it for budget type travel.

Cheap accommodation with easy access to oublic transport. While the rooms and bathrooms were tiny, we couldn't complain for the price. If you're looking for luxury and space, this hotel is not for you. The reason it gets such a high rating however, is because the staff here are excellent. Always willing to point you in the right direction and with free walking tours and other events, they made our stay exceptional.

It was a nice experience to stay in Sakura Hatagaya Hotel during my trip. The staffs are kind and helpful. It was easy to access tourism spot in Tokyo, e.g. just 9 minutes to go to Harajuku from the hotel.

The hotel location is good. The hotel café also offers Halal food. Furthermore, there are two Halal restaurants nearby (Pakistan & Indian). Hope there will be more varieties of Halal food added into the hotel cafe menu e.g Halal Japanese sushi, ramen etc. in the future.

This hotel was booked for our last night in Tokyo and it met our expectations for a budget hotel. A lot of tourists from all over the world stay here and the front desk staff speak good English. I didn't bother with the 400 yen breakfast as it only had toast and miso soup. Location is close to subway and plenty of restaurants and shopping centers.

I had a pleasant stay here at Sakura Hotel - thank you! It made my stay in Tokyo very enjoyable! :) Location: Once you arrive at Shinjuku station, you will need to take the Keio New Line and get off at Hatagaya Station! (Be prepared for a fair walk to arrive at this line) The ticket from Shinjuku Station to Hatagaya (and vice versa) will cost you 130 Yen, (this is the minimum fare, anyway, from what I could see) unfortuantely this is not covered by the 3 day metro pass that I bought. (Buy a ticket from the machine) It was the second stop, after getting on the train at Shinjuku. *As soon as I came out of the South Exit, I turned left! (I did not go through any traffic lights, or cross any major roads) Then I headed towards the Family Mart on the corner, which is a convenience store (Green and blue border). You should get there in one minute! Once I was standing on the corner, where Family Mart is, I turned right! There it was :) I could see the hostel sign from the corner (The hotel was also on the right hand side of the road).Positives: The staff all had very good levels of English, and were very helpful! (lovely, too) Thank you! They knew the needs of international travellers! The simple all you can eat breakfast of toast, spreads, soup, juice, etc etc was tasty and very convenient.There were facilities to wash and dry your own clothes (coin operated) The location was convenient and relatively close to ShinjukuThere were 2 computers available for use in the lobbyThere was a traditional Japanese bathhouse within a very short walk (staff gave me directions) There were places to eat very close by, and a convenience store. The café was always open The front counter sold 1-3 day metro passes.Neutral: The room, including the bathroom, was very "compact" though that didn't bother me. Areas for improvement: The water piping in the roof was quite noisy, (regular sounds of water passing through) in both of the rooms that I was in. *Though it was stated that the washing machines and dryers shouldn't be used after 10pm at night, I found that this wasn't always enforced, and thus, in the rooms close to (and on the same floor as) the machines and dyers, noise from the washing and drying of clothes could be heard, which was disturbing at times. *When using my phone to access the wifi on higher floors of the hotel, it was difficult to pick up signal, and the wifi kept dropping in and out. Thank you! I would stay here again!

The town of Hatagaya is a very local town. I used to live a station away, and around the Hatagaya Station is a good place to eat and do local shopping.You could walk to Shinjuku or take a train(2 stations away), or take bus to Shibuya. One good thing I like about this hotel is, there's a "Sentou"(Japanese Public Bath) called "Kan'non-Yu" is located in about 300m North of Hatagata Station. You need to bring towels, shampoo, etc. but you could buy them at the venue too. Since "Kan'non-Yu" is a public bath for local people, you need to be familiar with Japanese style prior to go there. Taking the bath is about 300 Yen, and towels and shampoo are additional if you don't bring them. Enjoy Japanese Bath!

Stayed for 4 nights in November. Excellent value for money. Easy to access to Tokyo - only 2 stations away from Shinjuku, train station is just around the corner from the hotel. Staff were very helpful and spoke English very well. Room was small but functional - although this is the standard in Japan. Breakfast provided every morning was good - although a bit more variety would be good than just toast and bread rolls. Definitely recommend staying here if you are looking for an inexpensive yet nice hotel in Japan.

Enjoyed this hotel located in Hatagaya which is just 2 train stop from the famous and large Shinjuku Train Station. The rooms are small but very clean and functional with daily house-keeping. My room had a TV, hair dryer, small fridge, long shoe horn (which I used every day!)and is comfortable if you are a sole traveller. I really loved the attached cafe / restaurant which had a nice homely and social feel to it with lots of travel information, maps, a 24 hour cafe, a wide selection of beers and two Internet computers and Wifi. The all you can eat free basic no-frills breakfast was an added bonus. The neighbourhood is quiet and "quaint" and a family area - I noticed lots of "mama chan" bicycles. The only negative is that the hotel is not on the convenient Yamanote Train Line however it is only two train stop from it. Extended my stay for 2 extra days and would stay there again.

Visited this hotel in Sep'15, with family on our way to Sendai. Stayed for 03-nights.The hotel is conveniently located from the Railway Station. 2 min walk from Hatagaya station (Subway Keio-New Line,)Check-in is possible from 3 P.M; Check-out is 10am. All Rooms in this hotel are non-smoking. Personal safe in room not available but they could keep your belongings upon request. Coin operated washing machines available from 10am to 10pm.Rooms have free LAN cable connection, Wi-Fi at the cafe. Laptops available on rent. Breakfast is available from 5AM to 11AM in the cafe for 365 yen/ person. Breakfast is very basic (juice, bread, tea/coffee/muffins; anything extra like a boiled egg will be charged extra). A Family Mart store is very close to the hotel. Ample restaurants are available within close proximity to the hotel (within walking distance)The tariff applicable during my stay (Sep'15) was :Corner double room is for 13,400 yen per room per night.Double room is for 9,300 yen per room per night.Single room is for 7,150 yen per room per night.Rooms are very small. Tokyo is a very expensive city, and hence this hotel may appear expensive. Bathroom is small but well designed. It serves all your basic needs. This is not even a semi-luxury hotel. The operations are managed by a team of young boys and girls who are very efficient and helpful

Good service and friendly staff. They serve Halal food for Muslim and they have prayer room. The location in Hatagaya is also near to Masjid Tokyo Cami within 15 minutes walk. Very near to station and only two stops to Shinjuku taking Keio New Line. I love this place.

I picked this Hotel because it was good priced and also just around the corner from the Hatagaya Subway Station.The main problem I had was that the Room had an overwhelming smell of mould, Probably because the wall was actually covered in mould. and that the bathroom smelt bad. Luckily the window opened so I just opened it when I got back so I could breathe.And the other issue I had was a rude staff member when I invited my friend to my hotel room to give her a gift for 30 seconds, she got spoken to rudely for coming up to my room with me like she was a prostitute or something. Not on.The room was small which was fine and expected, and more than enough room for one person. Pretty sure pillow had rocks in it, and felt every bit of the mattress.Free Wifi in room was great and very useful when travelling. I did not make use of the cafe but it looked to be cosy

This place was my base!The hotel was clean and tidy, my room was big enough for my needs. Breakfast (unlimited coffee, toast and jam) was okay to fuel me up for the day ahead!!Once I stopped getting lost walking back from Shinjuku station and the bad weather cleared up (nothing the hotel staff could do about that!!), this hotel was in a pretty good position to get to where I wanted to visit. The staff were very helpful with finding information and directions for me on their computer!Would recommend!

Visited in April, 2015.The food there is great, the cafe is just amazing for food and people regularly come to just eat at the Sakura hotel.The hotel staff are excellent with their service and were quite happy for us to leave some baggage at the hotel whilst we travelled around. All staff spoke English and would go out of their way to help you get to where you wanted to.The rooms are small, albeit extremely functional and clean. They had all the amenities you would expect of a 4 star hotel and more. Made for a comfortable and enjoyable stay.

The building itself shows some wear and tear. But the location, and most of all the ambience among the international guest and staff makes up for this. The staff have good knowledge about attractions and how to get there, and are in every way very helpful. The lobby area has a 24/7 open cafè, serving excellent coffee, a vide selection of beer, and small hot dishes. They have a muslim prayer room.

The room and service of Sakura Hotel Hatagaya is as good as it used to be since I chose to stay there from 2009.Only one thing I would like to comment on is the size of the shower area in my room - #501 is extremely small! I am not a large size person but I feel it is very difficult to move inside the shower tub.

Pros: Great service, good value, convenient location, helpful staff, free wifiLocation: The main station for all our travels is Shinjuku, but Shinjuku is so overwhelming, so we are always glad to return to Hatagaya (2 stations away).We are a family of four. Most hotels want us to book 2 rooms. Here we got a 2 twin bedside in a room, own bathroom, small fridge. It has a homely atmosphere, great value, great staff who speak great English and are always willing to help you out with your tourist questions. The room is serviced daily, new towels everyday. Breakfast is basic, yet adequate to get your day started. The soup is nice. Nearby is a great supermarket Gourmet city where we bought our supplies, including dinner. They have great food, from sandwiches, to bento boxes, noodles, sushi, salad, seafood eg grilled squid, fried fish and octopus tentacles, etc.

I recommend it no every traveler. It's very near Hatagaya station. And u have almoust everything around you. Very friendly staff. The rooms are very clean. And there is washing machine and dryer on the 5th floor.

It is located near the train station. Around it are groceries, bars, restaurants, convenience stores and a lot more.I wish they would offer more of breakfast, aside from unlimited bread, butter and jam. There are other things in the menu but those are not included in the breakfast buffet.

The size of the room can be a bad aspect if you dont stand limited space, but if you want to explore Tokyo, it have a excellent, and i mean, excellent ubication!! At just seconds from Hatagaya station of the subway, its easy to connect with all the mayor lines of transportation in the city!!! I fully recomend it!!!

It is a good hotel. Muslim friendly hotel. Provide halal food. The staff were friendly and very helpful. Despite of so many questions asked through email, the response were positive and encouraging. the hotel is very near to Hatagaya Station. Near to family mart too. The hotel willing to help when needed.

Rooms are tiny, but once you get acclimated, you realize the rooms have everything you need. Since we spent little time in our room, the size of the room did not bother us. The hotel is clean and the staff provide excellent customer service. The staff speak English and are helpful and professional. The location is excellent as Hatagaya station is just a couple minutes away and there are a number of restaurants within walking distance.The breakfast is limited, but is enough to get you started for the day. I would recommend this hotel for budget minded travelers who do not plan to spend much time in their hotel room.

Certainly a no frills hotel (a step above a hostel), but the staff were friendly and spoke English well. There were 4 of us (2 adults, 2 kids) and the room was spacious as we got the corner room, which had an extra foyer sized room where we put our luggage. Laundry facilities were handy and was not expensive (250 yen including detergent for washing machine and 400 yen for 2 hours in dryer). We had buffet breakfast included in our stay, but that was very simple: toast, jam, sliced baguette, tea/coffee, juice and soup (which was pretty much clear stock). We got there on the Chiyoda line and it was 1.1 km walk from the station (uphill walk in some areas so quite tiring for the kids). Hotel located close to convenience stores and restaurants.

Two stops from Shinjuku, Sakura Hotel Hatagaya has small but clean rooms and a price I really don't think you can beat. Don't expect luxury, but enjoy the atmosphere and convenience of a friendly place.

It's recommended hotel if you want budget type. The hotel can be easily accessed from Haneda airport eaither by train or bus and near to Shinjuku as a transit place. There are many restaurants and meals shop near the hotel so you don't have to worried about your food.

Before arriving at the hotel my expetations weren't particularly high. First, the rent is very cheap when you take the season and the general prices in Tokyo into consideration, and second, last year I stayed at another Sakura Hotel which was perfectly fine but also fairly average. Having said that, I was pleasantly surprised by the Hatagaya establishment; the staff was really sweet, they helped us with all the things we had trouble finding out on our own because of language difficultuies, they took an interest in our plans for the holiday, and most of them spoke English very well. The hotel itself was always clean and tidy, which was also very true for the rooms. The only thing to be aware about is the location. Personally, I really liked that it was a more quiet area, there was little noise, and though there wasn't as much to do at night, or as many different eating places as you find in more central parts of the city, it had its own charm; we even found a small park where the children played baseball matches on Sundays. All in all I really liked the hotel, the staff and the placement. If I ever go back to Tokyo, there is no doubt in my mind that I would go back here as well.

We stayed here for 3 nights hoping it would be a good base for Tokyo, it was only 2 subway stops fron Shinjuku but a long walk through the station to get to the correct platform. Hotel itself was nice, clean and small, as per all Japanese hotels are. The free breakfast was nothing special but appreciated.Would recommend to those on a budget for a central base, but those looking for late night outs might want to look elsewhere.

With a city like tokyo who want to sit INSIDE a hotel all day or for that matter all night!even tough rooms were small small bed etc it was clean and PERFECT for a good nights sleep..easy acces to subway walking distance and enough stores for foodstaff was friendly and helpful was happy i stayed well worth the money

The Sakura Hotel Hatagaya is great value for those on a budget whwo don't necessarily want to share a room. The bed wasn't massive, the room was cosy, the bathroom small but well fitted, a small bar fridge to hold drinks or food. The room was more than adequate for what we needed it for. This isn't the sort of room you spend hours in awake but thats ok because chances are you'll be runnning around toyko having fun. Cheap, easy and secure.

Backpacking all over Asia becomes expensive in a country like Japan, so I booked four nights at the Sakura and it's been just great.Easy to find from the close Hatagaya station, check in ran smoothly and the guy was friendly and professional.Space in Tokyo comes at a premium so do not expect an enormous bedroom, just a French bed attached to the wall and little space to walk around. For me and my friend was perfect, couldn't ask for more.If you want to save money but you think you will stay at the grand palace then just don't book there and then complain about it :-)The breakfast is simple: bread, jam, butter, soup, juice,coffee, tea and milk and its included in the price but if you want other things you can order and pay extra.The location is fab, just two stops to Shinjuku and if you feel like walking, like we did one day, in 35/40 minutes you are in Harajuku and Omotesando, then you can always catch a train to Shibuya or back to Shinjuku.Great stay,

Small rooms,small beds,small bathroom, small elevator (can only fit 1-3 persons), small breakfast choices, hotel was hard to find for a first timer like me. Great staff, has free wifi, near a Family mart.

Positives:- Very clean with the full amenities provided- Wifi is good- Staff are extremely friendly and helpful- Luggage storage is provided before and after check-in/check out- Most helpful were all the free guides available in the lobby! They’ve got a big stand with all the very helpful tourist maps, Timeout map suggestions. They’ve also got a suggested itinerary that they’ve created themselves of the nearby attractions. It was really handy to be able to select what I needed especially as the hotel was my first stop in Japan- Good restaurants nearby as well as a local bakery and several convenience stores- Quiet (in a residential area)- Good value for the location- Although the “outside” area is closed after 10/11ish, the café in the lobby area is open 24hrs and they are very happy for you to chill out there- For those who are looking for Muslim-friendly hotels, I believe that they have a prayer room and that they have an appropriate menu at the cafeConsiderations:- Breakfast: the “buffet/all you can eat/free flow” breakfast comprised of only toast, soft bread rolls, butter and jam. I suggest stopping by the great local bakery on your way out of the hotel towards the station- Location: For those who found this hotel listed on websites as being within the Shinjuku or Shibuya area, I would warn that it’s a little further away. It’s about a 10min metro ride to Shinjuku or a 25min walk. - Size: yes it’s on the small side but then again, I wasn't in Tokyo to stay in a hotel room so I had no problem with the room size.- It’s a quiet area but the walls are quite thin, so you’ll hear any noisy neighbours

Good Hotel. Good Location. Good Service. Be aware there is nothing western for breakfast except for toast. Hotel was very clean and had no issues at all during my stay. I would happily come here again.

We stayed here for two nights. The room space is very confined and we had to keep our luggage under the bed. It is however fairly clean and has all the basic amenities like toiletries, slippers, kimono robes and hair dryer.Hotel is located in a residential zone, and by 10 pm, the staff do not allowed guests to sit on the chairs outside the hotel. Breakfast is mostly the same, bread, rolls, coffee on free flow. We were told by one kitchen staff that the tap water was safe for drinking.There are few convenience stores nearby. We enjoyed the quiet location and clean surrounding. The hotel is less than 5 mins walk from Hatagaya station, which is served by the New Keoi Line.

Perfectly located, awesome staff and overall a very enjoyable experience.It all depends on what type of traveller you are. The rooms are small, and it is a lively place. So if you are the type of traveller looking for a trip where you stay and do all at the hotel, this may not be for you....But on the other hand, if you take time to talk with the staff, get their advices on where to go and what to do, you are sure to discover Tokyo and have a great time. Take a minute to speak with Ken or Yuki and you won't regret it.We originally intended to only stay 3 days but returned for 2 more days since we really enjoyed our time there. Btw, the price is great for the area...and I suggest the corner room if available !

Just read the other reviews, most of them 4 or 5 star. I won't repeat, but so glad I found this place, I extended my one week stay to two weeks. Room IS small, but I got used to it. Very clean and well maintained throughout. Retaurant area great place to eat and meet people. All other hotels I've stayed at (up to £150), the staff were OK but had virtually no English and were no help to me - here at Sakura, all the staff had many languages and were eager to help the whole time.Nearly unbelievably so! Ideally placed close to subway to explore ANYWHERE in Tokyo, I would certainly return here if in Tokyo.Thank you so much: Yuki, Taiyo, Kei, Aya and Ken - and all the others.

Stayed 10 nights, booked 3 double rooms as we had 3 chilrens and 6 adults.Good Location as it is near train station, rooms is indeed clean, friendly hotel staff. The only disadvantage would be the limited space (but we are mentally ready). Given the rental fee, i still think this would be a worthwhile hotel for budget traveller.

The hotel: The twin room was more spacious than expected, with one single and one double bed. The room and bathroom were spotless and towels and toiletries were replaced daily. The café looked quite nice and had a selection of beers, though we mostly stuck to the vending machines outside (which had HOT coffee cans!) A few tables outside made a nice smoking/relaxing area after a long day. The staff: Most seemed to speak good English and were very helpful and friendly. It was probably the only place in Japan where they tried to make small talk. The area: Hatagaya deserves a special mention as an absolutely charming residential area. The quiet, narrow main street has a number of beautiful shops and feels a world away from the madness of Shinjuku. Right behind the hotel is a walking path through the neighbourhood lined with cherry trees. In the blossom season, this was one of the most beautiful places I saw in Tokyo, with many families out with picnic baskets and bottles of wine. Location: The hotel’s just a few steps down from Hatagaya station, which is two stops away from Shinjuku station on the Keio New Line. It sounds easier than it is. Because the Keio line platform in Shinjuku is quite a few flights of overcrowded stairs and escalators away from the JR line platforms. And after a long, long day of walking, it’s not something you look forward to. Luckily, the hotel is close enough from Shinjuku/Shibuya to take a cab and not cause a financial crisis. Overall: A great little affordable hotel in a beautiful area. Not as easy as staying near a JR station, but worth the extra effort, esp. during the Cherry blossom season.

Staying one night with my wive and 10 years old son. All the staff were very friendly, helpful and can speak English. The hotel had praying room and halal food for lunch, it is suitable for moslem traveler. The room was very small but clean and had free wifi. I met traveler from Indonesia and Malaysia too.

We stayed here for one night on a short visit to Tokyo. For whatever reason, we thought the hotel was in Shinjuku when we booked, however, it is in Shibuya, but closer to Shinjuku Station (just 2 stops on the local line) than Shibuya Station (2 stops with a transfer to the JR at Shinjuku). Once we got our bearings, we had no trouble getting around on the nearby metro stop located just two blocks away from the hotel. The room was clean but very small. I mean, we had to coordinate movements to get dressed and move about to get to the shower or access luggage. Nonetheless, the staff was friendly and helpful, breakfast was very standard--coffee, juice, breads (enough to get our days started), check-in and check-out were both seamless, and the wi-fi worked well. It was a decent stay for a good price.

Pros:- Excellent Location- Friendly and Helpful Staff- Great opportunity to meet other travelers- Free Wifi- definitely comes in handy considering many people do not use Smartphones, and wifi hotspots are VERY HARD to come by- Clean RoomsCons:- Small rooms (but not a big deal, considering most rooms in Japan are not large to begin with)- Noisy bathrooms- No luxurious amenities (i.e. pool, gym)

It's just two train stations away from shinjuku station thus making it easy to get back after a whole day of going around the places in Tokyo. The neighborhood is quiet and there are many convenient stores in the area. The staff was friendly and accommodating, they would go out of there way to suggest different available rooms just to accommodate their guests (we were three and we stayed at four different rooms during our 9day stay). The room which we least liked is the corner double room because it was very cramped and there was a concrete post blocking the way to the bed. Also, most of the rooms that we stayed at was also not cleaned up thoroughly, there were still some traces of hair in the carpet and the bathroom. They also didn't have a kettle in the room. Nevertheless, we enjoyed our stay since it was conveniently located, the room rates was within our budget and the staff were really accommodating.

The hotel staff is very friendly.. They help you always with ur questions. Quiet location, yet very close to the train station in Hatagaya. Also, they have a free walking tour tour of a local flea market every sunday which is quite nice to mingle with others staying at the hotel and also have a good view of people's lifestyles. Only problem was very limited breakfast options.

But not by much. I've stayed in places with bathrooms that stank more, but that was a campground with no flushing toilet. I've stayed in places with harder beds, but again, camping. This is definitely a place for young people who don't know better, or people who don't mind the deprivations of a cheap hotel. It's one saving grace is that it's close to the station. Did I mention the bathroom stank? It was as though the pipe had no s-bend and we could smell the sewer. It was gross.

This hotel is in a pretty good location in a quiet suburb ~25 minutes walk from Shimokitazawa. Very close to a train line - this train is 2 stops from Shinjuku (which goes anywhere). STRONGLY recommend that you walk around the backstreet of as it is a beautiful area with small old houses around. Quite near the super-trendy Shimokitazawa.

I book a single room with private bathroom, was great not only a nice size room was very clean and calm, the area is very nice I discover only few block a nice wood with small restaurants, cafes and vintage stores, also a public bath few block from the hotel. Breakfast was nice and started really early, you can walk from there to a major area. From there you need to take the metro in order to go into the train and get into major stations, then is more expensive to travel, but is worth it.People who are working there really made an effort to make you feel home I love it.

+ve: -Good location with train station nearby and many restaurants and stores nearby-Good breakfast spread at a reasonable price -Umbrella was available for renting when it was raining-Staff was kind, helpful & spoke good english-ve:-wifi at the corner double room was weak-the steps near the entrance made it difficult to transport luggage in and out of the hotel

This hotel is a good budget hotel. It is only a few mins walk from Hatagaya station. Rooms are small but clean, warm and tidy and the staff are fantastic and very friendly. Ideal for travellers who just need accomodation for one night, or for backpackers as it has that vibe in the communal areas.
user_location: Abel Tasman National Park, New Zealand

review_body: This is the noisiest hotel I have ever stayed in, between each concrete wall, 2 rooms are crammed in together where I think once was 1 complete room. With the thin walls you can hear your neighbors & your neighbors can hear you. There's noisy piping in the thin walls & the water pump constantly fires up. There's no kettle & no wardrobe. If you add breakfast all you get is bread, tea, coffee & soup. The washing machine & dryer have a set use time of 10:00-22:00 because they're located in the corridor. The washer & dryer should have been placed on the 8th floor. I checked there's space there. The only good thing is it's close to Hatagaya train station.

People always say that you get what you pay for but in the case of the Sakura Hotel in Shibuya you get a lot more. Yes, the rooms are small even for Tokyo but the location is fantastic, the price is right, you can get a cheap breakfast, and the fellow travelers make it a great environment where you can meet people from around the world in a comfortable setting. I am told it is listed on hostel sites world-wide and the cross section of English speaking travelers would back this up. It has a youthful vibe with an open area in the lobby / restaurant where you can meet fellow travelers. I was there on business but most of the people staying there were simply on vacation seeing the sites. The staff speaks excellent English and were extremely helpful. The hotel is literally two streets (alleyways) on the right out of the south entrance of the Hatagaya station off the New Keio line (Keio #4 in Shinjuku station). If you take more than 5 minutes to find it you have gone too far.There are a number of good restaurants on the main street from the station and it sits in an upscale residential area so you can wander around with no issues. The Sunday I was there one of the staff took a tour group over to Meiji Shrine and the local flea market. We ended up at a fantastic okanomitaki restaurant afterwards. It seems that the group that owns the Sakura hotel chain also owns an art gallery, and various restaurants which this is one of them. The gallery next store to their restaurant was worth visiting too for some unique items. Ask for directions from the staff.The Internet is free and there are small stores across the street and up the block (Family Mart). Breakfast is simple Japanese soup, toast, or some rolls with juice but it is enough to get you up and going. If you want a classic business room like the Hyatt stay in Shinjuku but if you want to experience more of what real Tokyo is like try this out.

During my trip in Japan in 2013 I stayed in Tokyo one week. In Sakura hotel I stayed one night and I would recommend this hotel. Lacation of hotel and price are very good. Hotel is located in very quite part of Tokyo with a lot of parks and houses around. Also if you want to be a part of Tokyo crowd, subway station is near the hotel and very quickly you can be in Shinjuku or Shibuja where you can enjoy in shopping malls, restourants and caffes. Staff of the hotel is very polite and service is good. Rooms are clean. In the lobby of the hotel is piano, you can play it and enjoy with your traveler buddies:)

I would highly recommend this hotel for budget conscious travellers. It's conveniently located 2 subway stops from Shinjuku (a great area that has many restaurants, night life & shopping) - all other areas of Tokyo are easily accessible through Shinjuku Station.The staff are very friendly & helpful. The breakfast is simple but good. The rooms are clean & well maintained. And the wifi connection is excellent. Plus if you need anything, there's a really good 24 hour supermarket a few minutes walk away.The only negative I can mention is that the water flowing through the plumbing in the walls is audible.

As a couple and moving a bit around Tokyo every night, we were really happy to see that the hotel is well located. Just 2 minutes, walking distance from the subway station. We arrived a bit early and the room wasn't ready, however the staff said that they could keep our luggages as we could enjoying our afternoon without an additional weight of 20Kg. The atmosphere is really friendly, and the staff really helpful. This hotel is really nice for backpackers as you can meet a lof of different nationalities on the lobby. It will respect a strict budget but will offer you a cosy room to sleep. (A bit small for 2 persons and 2 luggages). The breakfast is a bit limited but we just needed a cup of coffee and a glass of juice. Places around are really nice as well, a delightful okinawa atmosphere bar, and few typical restaurants. We really enjoyed our stay in this hotel and we won't forget to come back.

The staffs are friendly & well english spoken. Hotel is 2 minutes walk from Hatagaya subway station and 2 stops from Shinjuku station. There are several 24-hour convenient stores and super market too. The location is not crowded.Double room has less walking space but clean. Stocked with basic amenities such as mini fridge, hair dryer, a deep tub, shower gel and shampoo, tv, hangers, desk and chair. The bed is comfy.

Hotel is 2 minutes walk from subway station and 2 stops from Shinjuku station. If you use Google map, you can walk to and fro Shinjuku, just 15 minutes. Shin Okubo station which is linked to JR is 15 minutes walk away. Many eateries (cheap to mid price) nearby. Try the Okinawa restaurant - reasonably priced and delicious. There's a Tomods (toiletries and drug store), several 24-hour convenient stores and one 24-hour super market too.Room is tiny but is stocked with enough basic amenities such as mini fridge hair dryer, a deep tub for soaking, shower gel and shampoo, tv, hangers, desk (no chairs). No electric kettle but you can get water from cafe. My boyfriend and I are Asians (1.8 and 1.6 metre tall) and the queen sized bed is fine for us. We have medium sized luggage and it's hard to move around with the luggage on the limited floor space. Ceiling and door frame are low - huge people might feel they are in tiny world haha! I don't like that there's a faint sound of water running at night when the neighbors use the tap so prepare ear plugs if you are a light sleeper.The English speaking staff's service was good - friendly and helpful. Overall a good budget hotel in Tokyo. You have to pay about USD$20/night more than this if you want bigger rooms so be realistic.
