The location near st hatagaya, its only 2 stfrom shinjuku st( main st). Easy to travel along tokyo area. The hotel staff very helpfull, the hotel location near convinience store also the hotel restaurant provide with halal food. It makes my travelling easier.

Friendly, helpful staff. Room is a bit small, hardly any place to walk around. But it's clean, functional, bed is comfy and everything works well. The location is very central to eateries, train station, supermarket, etc. great spot.

Location is about 100 metre to Hatagaya train station but abit far from Narita Airport. (1 1/2 hrs). Strategically located to move around Tokyo. At first I stay in double room but its too small, no space to put luggage. Moved to corner double room for remainder 3 night.Staff very friendly and helpful.Halal food was available (Brahim) and prayer room was provided for muslim customer. room and toilet very clean and houskeeping was done everyday.

The location is near the train station and many restaurant, grocery store, convenient stores around the area. The location is not crowded, it quiet. There are few tables outside for alfresco dining.The double room offered is very small, no space to move around and to store luggage. More of a budget type hotel.The breakfast served is Western style, I hope next time they can serve Japanese breakfast.The staffs are friendly and speaks English very well, eager to give directions.

very good location with lots of eateries around the area, very near the subway, clean rooms, quiet neighborhood. clean rooms, towels are changed everyday, a good place to stay if you're on a budget! :)

Very cute hotel! It's locate is very comfortable - only 2 minutes to metro and 1.45 hour to Narita airport, + friendly speaking english staff! In bar you can find very good choice of beer))))In the room you can find everything you need, it's very pleasant for 3* hotel, your room is cleaned every day and staff bring you a small toothbrush and toothpaste))

Pros: Nice staff. Close to subway station. Quiet low key area. Young vibe. Helpful staff. Lots of different beers for sale. Cafe on site serves food. Cons: More hostel than hotel (it's listed on some hostel websites). Not on main subway line which means you'll have to pay about $2 each time you switch from the main subway line to the private line. This also adds time to your travel. Breakfast is a bit of a joke - drinks and bread. Tiny tiny rooms even by Japanese standards. Bit shabby. Could probably book a cleaner, newer, business hotel with more amenities and in a better location for about a bit more.

This is a western style hotel. The hotel is nice located, and has like most hotels in Japan small rooms that are very clean. There is a fridge in the room. There is an internet-cafè in the lobby open 24/7, with the friendly front desk staff serving drinks and snacks if needed. They have a really big selection of beers to choose from. The staff answer all kinds of questions and give good advice about sight-seeing, which trains to take and so on. The guests come from all parts of the globe. The staff also comes from many different countries, and many different languages are spoken. The hotel promote agriculture without poison. The ambience all over is always very good in this hotel. "Continental breakfast plus" is served from 05.00. There is a nice food store called Gourmet City in the next street, open 24 hour. Budget travellers might want to by food in the evening when prices are lower.

Stay for 6 nights, lovely atmosphere, even there were many young people was quit and calm. the staff was very helpful, the room was very comfy location very close to the station easy to find thank you

Sakura Hotel is definitely not high end, but for a home base in Tokyo I think it's a good choice. It caters mostly to business and young travelers who won't be spending a lot of time in their rooms or at the hotel. There are no activities, game rooms or such like. It's a place to sleep and maybe eat. The rooms are small. The single and double rooms you have to go outside to change your mind. Very very clean, the staff is helpful to a fault and very friendly. We have stayed there two years in a row and will go back. Hatagaya is in Shibuya, two stops from Shinjuku so it's pretty much in the middle of Tokyo without being in the middle of "Tokyo." Hatagaya is like a village within the city, quiet and relatively slow moving. Lots of activity but not the hustle and bustle of the "center" of tokyo. a lot of people but no crowds.  A three minute walk from the hotel and you are on Koshu Kaido which is a real live main drag. The New Keio line subway station is right there and you can go anywhere in Japan from that station. Nishihara Machi (shopping street) is right next door and across Koshu Kaido are a couple more neighborhood shopping streets. The big stores are a couple of subway stops away, but totally accessable. Shinjuku is right there. I think you could find just about anything you could immagine and then a whole lot more in Shinjuku.All together unless you are looking for something fancy and up scale, this hotel is a real find.

I thought i've wrote a review on this hotel but it must've been on another site. i was traveling around japan last july and came across this hotel.. becos nothing is cheap in japan so i had to spend as little as i can on accommodation. After eating some dodgy chinese food in yokohama i was coming down with a fever and headaches.. by the time i got to the hotel everything was closed except 7-11s.. which unfortunately didn't sell any medication to stop the fever.. so i went to the front desk to ask if they know where i can get some... the gentlemen manning the counter went into the backroom and got some of their own stash and gave it to me free of charge! without that my trip would've been pretty ruined.. once again thank u for doing more than what a budget hotel is expected and helped a traveller in need. ps. the bed was a little too soft for my liking

I stayed with my wife The staff were very helpfull when i need to book an extra night at Sakura Ikebukuro and they help to book. room was clean and quiet place and near station. Will back for stayed in japan again

Traveling to an entirely different country can be daunting, but the staff at Sakura Hotel were super friendly and made us feel right at home. The room was very small, for a couple with 2 luggages you can say goodbye to the living space. Breakfast is cheap but also very poor in term of choice. However the hotel is really well located near a station and there's a lot of small restaurants nearby.Don't spend more than 2 nights if you have to share a room.

I chose this place because I had stayed at the Sakura Hotel in Ikebukuro and found it ok. Also, the price was reasonable for Tokyo. The location was near to Shinjuku for getting about almost anywhere in the city but in a relatively quiet area. I did not need to call upon the staff for very much but found them helpful when required. I did need an umbrella one evening and really appreciated the free loan of one. Breakfasts were cheap but very basic and not to my taste so I did not try them. As expected, there was not much space in the room but all facilities including the lights and air-con worked very well. For wifi though I had to use the cafe or reception area downstairs.

- One thing about travelling alone is that its an exhileratingly terrifying experience. You are away from the familiarity and the sanctuary of your home. But as a stranger in a strange land, I found a place I could definitely call home in Sakura Hotel Hatagaya. - The rooms provides me with the space just enough for a solo travellor with free wifi in the room and in the common area as well. - The location is great too... for the price charged by this hotel. Hatagaya is a quaint neighbourhood with 'jems' to be found by any travellor who is willing to explore. The train station Hatagaya station is just a few steps from the Hotel and and the station is just a few stops from one of the main train stations in tokyo...Shinjuku Station. There are interesting places like the Shinjuku Sports centre for people who want to play sports and do gym and exercise and there is the Yoyogi park and Meiji Shrine which makes a great walk and photo opportunity. There are some interesting Restuarents and Cafes and even a Karoke neaby. - Not only that their website provides a lot of useful information and even detailed information on how to get to the hotel from both the main international airports in tokyo. - But most importantly the one thing that I would like to headline about this Hotel is its service. Its service staff: ones at the reception and tending the bar at their cafe' called the Sakura Cafe', are awesome and are people I would certainly 'hang out' with. They are friendly and keen to answer answer any question that you might have. And most importantly they can speak and understand good English. It's well enough that most solo travellors in japan have studied the language to some extent but its a relief when one gets home that he/she need not have to go through the hassle of remembering their Japanese...its a good moments reprieve. - The Sakura cafe' is a dime in a dozen for budget cafes. It provides interesting food and drinks from across the globe at reletively affordable prices. A great menu for a global customer base.  - One problem with Sakura cafe' is its breakfast. I dont hate it but I dont exactly love it either...one could get a more interesting breakfast at the Mcdonalds nearby who by the way ave some great tasting beef burgers strangely...The sakura cafe provides a 365 yen breakfast which is mostly the essentials - tea, coffee, toast, butter and jam (all you can eat). I hope that they could make the price for this breakfast a bit cheaper and have another 'deluxe' option where one could top-up to have a more interesting breakfast with more variety like pancakes or waffles or a healthy one like tasty oatmeal.All in all I will surely be coming back to my home away from home in Japan ... Sakura Hotel Hatagaya...A special shout out to the great people in the hotel, Yuki-san, Gao-san, Aya-san, Tomatsu-san, Kana-san and everyone else...See ya when I see ya.

The staff here was extremely gracious and always willing to help.....whether it was printing out maps for my girlfriend and I or explaining the subway system every one we encountered was more than willing to give us advice and assistance. Being only 2 subway stops from Shinjuku station (major public transportation hub) was very convenient. While the rooms are tiny and the breakfast simple I would stay here again for sure.

stayed at Sakura Hatagaya hotel for 4 nights. When I saw the room, I was disappointed to the old furniture, a lots of dust under the bed and sofa. Specially there were moldy in the bathroom.. I didn't want to stay here anymore. And the breakfast was so simple and not good taste. It was not worthy even 365 yen. Anyway my experiment of staying at Sakura hatagaya hotel was awful.

The location of the hotel, which is like a youth hostel, is good. 2 stops from Shinjuku Station. The staff is very friendly and they speak good english. The rooms are much too small and we just showed up for sleeping. The lobby is nice and you have wifi there. We did not like the breakfast-too much white bread and too much garbage and wrapping for the small butter and jam. The area there is nice and there´s a good thai restaurant in walking distance.

I've stayed at Sakura Hotel before at the Ikebukuro location, which I enjoyed very much but this was my first time at Hatagaya. The place is a bit smaller but the quality and cleanliness of everything remains just as great. It's conveniently located very close to the Keio New Line Hatagaya station (like 1 minute walk), a post office, a convenient store, a bookstore, a Mos burger, Origin Bento, and many other food locations. The front desk is staffed 24/7, as well as their cafe! English-speaking staff, free WiFi (though weak at high traffic periods), cleaned room everyday, etc, these are just some of the perks for a cheap price. If you're going to book a stay, and I highly recommend you do, make sure to check out their Special Offers page, there's usually something useful there. Have a great stay!

If I were to use conventional hotel criteria, I would rate it 2 stars. I am trying to be generous by using hostel criteria. I noticed the hostel self-description only upon arrival, so the shortcomings made more sense.My wife and I first stayed at a budget business hotel near the Ningrocho metro stations for 2 nights before moving to Sakura Hatagaya for additional 2 nights in Tokyo. Although the 2 places charged nearly the same price per night, the quality of accommodations were night and day. I'm not used to hostels, so I may be judging the Sakura Hatagaya too harshly. Again, my reference point is the fact that I paid the same price for a hostel room as a real hotel with new-looking furnishings located 2 blocks from a Metro station.Location. Theoretically, it's 2 train stops from Shinjuku, but it involves additional cost and walking distance. The Keio New Line is neither part of the Tokyo Metro/Toei system nor the JR Rail system, so this fare is additional to any JR Rail Pass or Tokyo subway pass. We were lugging two large suitcases from the Shinjuku metro station to the Shinjuku Keio station, not realizing that the walking distance was considerable, especially when some stairs did not have escalator or elevator alternatives. While the hotel is a short distance from the Keio Hatagaya station, the hassle of getting to other parts of Tokyo was considerable.Condition of facilities. The outdoor cafe seating had a nice feel, but the hotel lobby felt worn and outdated. It felt like time stopped in the 60's or 70's.The walls, furniture and carpeting all could use renovation and updating. The elevator was small, so often it was wall-to-wall with people. The staff, though, were friendly and helpful. Condition of room. Our room was similarly worn and tired looking. Of the 3 places we stayed in Japan, our Sakura Hatagaya room was the smallest. Literally, we could not open our 2 suitcases on the floor at the same time. We learned to use the space under the bed to store our suitcases. The comforter did not have a separate quilt cover, so I did wonder how often the staff washed the comforters. The a/c was directed right at our faces while in bed, so there was an uncomfortable draft all night. I wish I had duct tape to secure a towel in front of the a/c vents to re-direct the air flow away from our faces. My absolute worst pet peeve was the shower curtain. It was so narrowly positioned that it was inevitable that it would adhere to my body while I was trying to soap up or rinse off. It reminded me of the old days of cruising when ships had tiny shower stalls with nylon curtains that would wrap themselves to one's body. It helps to open the shower curtain half-way when you're trying to soap up.Breakfast. It's literally white sliced bread, sliced french bread, dinner rolls, soup/broth of the day, juice of the day, generic coffee and tea bags. Toasters were available for breads and rolls. We managed by supplementing our breakfasts with yogurts and fruits bought at nearby convenience stores and markets.The Sakura provided a 24-hour lounge space (breakfast room) for those who want to surf the Internet or work at their laptops (given rooms have no desks). Outlets are available at a couple of tables.In my opinion, I much prefer a budget business hotel rather than a hostel (given relatively the same cost). Ironically, it probably takes less time to get to Shijuku/Shibuya from a cross-town hotel near a Metro station than from the Sakura Hatagaya.For me, the Sakura barely gets a 3-star (even for a hostel).

I stayed at Sakura Hotel Hatagaya for a week whilst I was in Tokyo. Hotel was slightly out of the way in terms of travel, 3 min subway journey on Keio New Line to Shinjuku. Doesn't sound like much but when you're carrying a bag in 30 degree heat and 97% humidity that you're not used to, it's a struggle believe me! Also, your JR rail pass doesn't count on the Keio New Line, so you have to pay, which is annoying.Most staff were polite but some seemed stand-offish. Room was very small but clean. Small size didn't bother me too much as I am a small person, but even I struggled to fit into the bathroom and shower! I thought "If I were tall I wouldn't be happy with this". WARNING: the rooms have VERY thins walls. Man next door to me sounded like he was sitting next to me I could hear his Skype conversation so clearly and he snored so loud I could feel it vibrating through the wall as well as the noise! A good hammer on the wall soon put an end to that! Breakfast...hm. Disappointing. Now, I might be small but I like decent a breakfast. Especially in Japan as I was out every day in the heat walking from 8am to about 7pm at night, so I needed something to start me off in the mornings. Only breakfast provided is bread(and a toaster), tea/coffee, juice and soup. I kept a stash of fruit upstairs to munch on before I went out after breakfast. There is a Family Mart on the corner not a minute away from the hotel which is also handy after breakfast.Overall, I don't think I will stay here again as I don't think it was good value for money. The room was small with very thin walls (albeit clean), and the breakfast was meager. Location wasn't as ideal as I thought it would be either. I think if you are staying here for just one or two nights it's passable, but any more I would recommend you stay somewhere else that has better rooms, breakfast and location. An average stay.

We Initially had booked our accommodation at the Sakura Hotel Jimbocho but when we got there they said they had sent me an email informing us they had to move us to the much nicer Hatagaya Hotel instead (we didn't have internet access when it was sent) We kept the same price (saving us $80AUD) and they gave us a free beer each and 1,000 Yen for the transport, so thanks to the Jimbocho staff for that but onto the Hatagaya review.We knew upon check in we were having a twin room for 2 nights and had to be moved into a double for the 3 last nights. the twin had quite a bit of room and was comortable, the double we couldn't even open our suitcase without it being on the bed. Our rooms at the Hatagaya had a mini fridge and a bathroom which we wouldn't of had had at Jimbocho.There is a family Mart just meters from the Hotel where a staffer was nice enough to operate ticket kiosk to help us buy pro wrestling tickets, there is also a supermarket (Gourmet City) around the corner for a huge selection of unusual Japanese food.Now for the Negative, the only train line here is the Keio New Line and you are 2 stops from Shinjuku station this train line turns into the Shinjuku (Green) line so that's good if you are going somewhere near the middle of Tokyo (Jimbocho station has 3 different lines going through it) the major issue is that the only stations that even show the Keio New Line on the route/price maps were Shinjuku station and the ones on the actual line, this was very frustrating. Overall the Hotel was very good but next time in Tokyo I'll be staying on the Yamanote line or a place with multiple train lines going through it.

We bounced around to a few different locations during our visit to Japan and stayed in Sakura Hotel Hatagaya for only one night. The proximity to Hatagaya station was great. The staff was friendly and explained the details very clearly. The double room was a snug fit for two people and some luggage, but we were only there for one night and didn't need to unpack much anyway. Breakfast was good. I really enjoyed the corn soup. Overall it's a decent stay for a budget traveller.

The staff who checked us in was really rude. He quoted us the wrong amount when we were making payment. Refusing to check his system, I took the initiative to show him the email confirmation his colleague sent to me when I made my booking. The number of days, type of room, with/without breakfast was stated very clearly in the email. He kept reading the email and doing the calculation for the next 15mins. He got himself and us frustrated when he could not get it right. When he managed to get the amount stated in the email, he said, "THANK YOU FOR MAKING THINGS SO DIFFICULT!"1) He doesn't know how to read email? Everything was stated clearly in there.2) He can't do simple calculations?3) Is this customer service?We stayed one night, left the hotel for Hakone the following day and went back to stay for the next 2 nights. We were given a smaller room than the one we had before and also a really smelly toilet. Revenge or what, we don't know. We requested a change of room but the other triple room is occupied for that one night. The hotel manager called to apologise while we voiced about the rude staff whom checked us in. Been a good manager, he sided his staff and insisted that we have misunderstood his words. He said he will investigate but until now, there was no news from him.Toilets were smellyAircon was noisyNo water to the basin after you have flushed the toilet. You gotta wait a good 3mins or so. I would say, stay at your own risk!

Staying here for 7 nights and I got special price for it. The location is very convenient, just 5 minutes from Hatagaya Station. It made me easier to commute everywhere. Many restaurant surrounds the hotel which also offer cheap price. Even though the room was quite small, it was clean and comfortable.

The one week special is definetly a very good way to save some money if you stay longer than one week.The hotel staff is totally friendly and helps you whenever you need some help. They really helped me a lot figuring out where to go and what to see. The Location of the hotel is perfect: If you walk to the Shinjuku station it takes about 20 minutes. With the metro about 5. So you can get everywhere quite fast and easy.Around the hotel there are also a couple of supermarkets and really good restaurants (Sushi, Soba, McDonalds, Izakayas,...)The prices for drinks in the hotel are also cheap and they have a really good coffee. I can't say anything about the meals cause I went out every day for lunch and dinner.Rooms: I had a single room and I must say it was bigger than I thought. A small minus was that there wasn't much storage for your clothes but I managed to get along quite good with that.So overall I highly recommend this hotel to everyone who doesn't want to pay too much money and wants a nice room in a hotel with a very friendly staff and a good location. (I will definetely choose this hotel again for my next trip to Tokyo)

This hotel is in a great location, I could not have been happier! Hatagaya is a great area with a lot going on if you know where to look. Sakura Hotel is very close to the train station too, so access to anywhere in the city is easy. We were only at this place for one night, but would recommend to stay. Very helpful front desk staff, breakfast was adequate and bed was comfortable. Would stay here again.

This is my favourite hotel in Tokyo - partly for personal reasons (some really good memories), but mostly because it's really good. Cheap (especially considering you are near Shinjuku - actually within walking distance, if you do not mind a nice 25 minute walk through park and lovely back streets), friendly staff, reasonable conditions. The rooms are small, but you wouldn't get a bigger one in any of the business hotels nearby - in fact, they would be very much the same, only several thousand yen more expensive. Despite being a budget hotel, it's pretty clean and you get stuff like tooth brush, soap, night gown etc., which comes pretty handy. Also, there are numerous small restaurants, cafes and shops nearby, so you can easily get anything you need - and for a good price.

I was looking for a hotel for a family of four. I have searched for many places in Tokyo. I would need to book two double rooms. Somehow I found Sakura Hotel Hatagaya. It is reasonable priced. I have read many good reviews before I booked for 3 night stay. We flew to Narita Airport and took Narita Express to Shinjuku station. We looked for Keio New line. Hatagaya is only two stations away. After got out Hatagaya station, it took us about two minutes to get to the hotel. We checked in right before 6PM without any problem. Staffs were very friendly and answered any question we had in English. We walked in to the rooms. The room is small which is very typical in Tokyo. Right after settled in, we went out to street to find a traditional Japanese restaurant. The owners of the restaurant were very friendly. After the dinner, we walked around streets. There was Family Mart and 7-11. If you walked out to the big street, you can find Gourmet City which is a big super market. The hotel location is just very nice. Later in evening, I spoke to hotel staff Eddie and Tarmo about what to do in Tokyo. They showed me different map and what attractions we could go as a family. They also would look online to find out more detail answers. They really spent time with me to make sure my visit would go well. Later I found out Eddie was a professional Tour Guide. Did I find the right person how to visit Tokyo? I am very impressed with the staffs, most of them are young and full of energy. First day, we visited Asakusa temple, SkyTree, Tsukiji fish market and Tokyo Tower. All these places were accessible with subway all day pass which cost $1000 yen per adult which is a very economical way to go around Tokyo. Later in Saturday evening, we took Keio New line to Sasakuza which is one station down of Hatagaya on Keio New line however you can walk if you want. There were more shops in Sasakuza. By the time we finished the day, we just fell asleep in hotel bed very quickly. For the second day, we just walked around Shinjuku. One suggestion is that you can go to Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building observation deck in Shinjuku. When you are up there, you can see the city very well. The one good thing is that it is free. Also there are a lot of big department stores in Shinjuku which are nice to visit. Overall, I like the location and staff of Sakura Hotel Hatagaya. The hotel rooms are ok and clean. Breakfast included in our hotel rate was very good (I love the soap of the day). We will definitely stay at this hotel again. One more thing, we were asked by staff Mihoko (maybe wrong spelling) which she could have a picture with our family. There is a board in the hotel entrance full of hotel guest pictures which I found very interesting.

Staying at this small hotel was a good option. It's cheap and you get all the basic amenities you need for a pleasant stay in a private room. It's also near a station, so you can move easily in Tokyo. You can also have a nice walk and get to know the neighborhood, in order to get to Meiji Shrine, which is 30 minutes walking. The staff is very friendly and helpful. Ask them for options to have dinner or visit different places in Tokyo!The cons: the room I got had a small window and the view were some pipes. There was a lot of noise from the water running at night.

Stayed here for 6 nights! The room is pretty small (Tokyo standard, maybe). Easy access, just 2 metro stops from Shinjuku Station. A lot of eateries around. The staff can speak english very well. The down part is the toilet is super small, as size as airplane lavatory with additional bath tub and it's super smelly because there's no ventilation at all. And the toilet seater is just the normal one, not the typical japanese toilet with warmer and bidet, etc.The wall is really thin so we can heard people on the next room snoring, i don't know it's because the thin wall or that guy really snore too loud.

During a recent visit early April to Tokyo my Wife and I spent two nights in this hotel. We had previously stayed here and had some concerns re cleanliness, décor ,carpets etc.. Redecoration has taken place, new carpeting is in place and altogether a big improvement. Staff as ever it seems are mixed nationality and very welcoming and helpful.We had a pleasant room which cost us £135 for the two nights. This was a larger room than we had used previously, but at an increased cost! Rooms here are generally small by western measures but perfectly serviceable. If your resources run to it, try to get a "Queen Room"Breakfast is available but at an extra cost of 350 yen and consists of toast, soup, pastries and preserves, tea and coffee. There is free Wi Fi. There is a café facility and the outside terrace is available which runs across 24 hours but is not a problem. If you don't want to stay for breakfast, there are several local coffee shops serving very good coffee and sandwiches and pastries and some things you cannot identify but taste nice!! Sakura is a good location, being next to the post office, and very close to the New Keio line for trains into the city at a cost of 140yen single to Shinjuku. If you are staying a while in the area get a Pasmo Card which you can use on trains and buses.We would be happy to use this hotel again given the improvements made.

We are first user for this hotel . We found Great price. Great location. 2 stop only from sinjuku station . See keio new line for hatagawa. Great service.The room is small, the bathroom is super tini. But over all clean...... Awesome its woorth it for stay here.The poor thing is chek out 10am. Need to review. Normaly 12pm fir chekout. The breakfast need to upgrade for yogurt and cereal.

The sakura hotel Hatagaya is a charming place. Very simple, cheap, but clean and comfortable. The room are small, but there's a nice terrace and a café. Near Shinjuku, Yoyogi Park and Harajuku, it's ideally located.The staff is very helpful. A very nice place to stay in Tokyo if you are not looking for luxe and space.

We stayed in Sakura Hatagaya for three nights and enjoyed it a lot. Rooms are clean, large enough and with the included breakfast a great value for money. It is also a very good place to meet fellow travellers as well as locals with a friendly café open 24h (without being a rowdy party place). The atmosphere is very friendly and relaxed, without being noisy. The location is also relatively good and well communicated to nearby hotspots like Shinjuku and Shimokitazawa. They are also within a reasonable walking distance, as is Yoyogi park- one of my favourite places in Toyko and perfect for a weekend stroll.

I have never been in a conventional hotel like it.Everything thought of. Staff were kind, direct and at ease. Breakfast was cheap but I wish it was Japanese with some fruit and therefore more expensive.

even the room are small, the water pipe always making noise, overall, the hotel is good, we love the place, its clean, the staff are very helpful. we spent 3 days here, and its good. but anyway the other comments are right, you should called it a hostel instead a hotel.

Sakura Hotel Hatagaya is located in a very convenient area. Hatagaya station is located like 2 min away from the hotel and from there you take the Keio NEW Line (there's also a Keio Line, so notice that you take the Keio NEW Line, as Keio Line will not be stopping at Hatagaya station). The trains from Shinjuku and Hatagaya are arriving and departing within a decent time frame (I estimate that there was a 10 minutes stop between each train, but I didn't wait long for the next train). From Shinjuku station you can basically travel everywhere as the lines (as in other major cities) intersects with each other and you can transfer to other lines and etc. The Post Office is literally around the corner from the hotel entrance, and there's also an ATM there, which is able to take foreign credit cards. This ATM is open from 9AM-5PM on weekdays (at the time of my stay), but there's a 7/11 with an ATM that I think is open 24/7, located across the street from Hatagaya station, so approximately 5 mins away from the hotel. There's two shops close to the hotel, one Tomod (a lot of household articles, cosmetics and quick snack/food) and one FamilyMart (with a bit more of a selection of snacks and food). The Hotel also takes some foreign cards. The hotel is for Scandinavian standards, very decent, but the rooms are really tiny, but keep in mind that this is in Japan and the rooms are small here. Hairdryer is located in the room, along with a mini fridge. But an electric kettle isn't in the room, but hot water is accessible in the hotel "lobby", which also functions as an area for breakfast/lunch and etc. Sakura Hotel Hatagaya also offers meals for a decent price (coming from Norway and used to the price point there, and the currency equivalent is very in favour for Norwegian currency compared to Japanese). The food was great for the price you pay, and not bad in terms of taste. The staff here is very service-oriented, all very polite and nice! And they are able to communicate efficiently in English, so not knowing Japanese won't be a problem. The reception is open 24/7, so no matter what time it is, you are able to get some help from the staff any time. They are also very informative if you're wondering about different places in Tokyo to visit, and they also offer a free map of the Underground in Tokyo, which is a great thing to have when you're travelling around in the city and transferring to other lines and etc. I would definitely recommend you to stay in Sakura Hotel Hatagaya, or other Sakura hotels located around in Tokyo. I stayed here in April 2014, for a school trip for approximately one week, and it was a great stay. We were in total close to... 30 people in our group, and it was all handled well.

Well located small hotel, rooms are very very small, but also very clean and with private bathroom; the staff is very friendly and helpful. We stayed at this hotel for 11 nights and I don't have nothing to complain about. Im pretty sure is the best price you cans get in Japan for all the commodities you get. Just two stops from Shinjuku via New Keio Line and it has a Family Mart, Moss Burguer, Dotour and a Ramen Soup place literally 1 min walk

Hatagaya Station is located 4 min 2 stops away from Shinjuku Station, use the Keio New Line (NB: NEW, there is also a "Keio Line"). From Hatagaya Station you walk 2 min. The hotel has guests and staff from many countries. There is a friendly and open minded ambience. If you like to make new friends, I recommend this hotel. There is a very fine food-shop around the corner from the station, it is open all night, the name is Gourmet City. Ask hotell-staff for map. There are nice residential areas close to the hotel, good for walking trips and for studying Tokyo life. The hotel is non-smoking inside, but has a nice smoking "cafè-area" outside. Maybe the room-price is in the upper level when considering the bedrooms and the common area (lobby internet-cafè). But since I first visited, I always go there when I stay in Tokyo. It has a homely feel to it, which many people appreciate, and a very good location.

Stayed a night and met 2 lovely staff members yuki and honda... We drank beers with them when they finished and were friendly. Rooms small but very clean.Excellent English speakers, my flight was cancelled to Hokkaido so I went back and tried to stay 2 more nights...they were booked out but had one room spare and were happy to give it to me.Ate dinner with yuki and honda for 2 nights and was very enjoyable....Definitely the place to stay in hatagaya if you are on a budget or want to see the culture. AMAZING

I stayed here for 4 nights in January and had a pleasant stay.The price was reasonable and the location is very good. Hatagaya station is just 2 stops from Shinjuku and from there you can connect to anywhere in Tokyo. Also, if you were planning to head towards Asakusa, Senso-ji or the Tokyo Sky Tree then the line from Hatagaya takes you virtually the whole way there. A taxi back from Roppongi after the trains stopped running cost just over 3000 Yen. The room itself is quite small. Mine had a double bed (which took up most of the space) and a desk with a TV. There isn’t a wardrobe, but a clothes rail with a few hangers is provided. It was fine for me as I was staying alone, but if you were a couple it would probably be quite cramped. The adjoining private bathroom was also small, but was clean and shower worked well.The staff were friendly and happy to help with any questions asked. Breakfast was served in the mornings for 300 Yen which consisted of bread/juice/tea – it didn’t look too appetising so I didn’t have it, but plenty of other guests did. Wifi was provided free of charge both in the lobby and in your room. It stopped working a couple of times but generally worked very well.Overall, I would recommend this hotel and would stay here again when I come back to Tokyo.

The Sakura hotel in Hatagaya was somewhat affordable, compared to other hotels in the area. The location was pretty central even though it is off the Shin Keisei Line. It's very close to Shinjuku, and the subway line takes you there. The room itself was pretty small, but then again, it's Japan - most hotel rooms are small. The service was friendly and accommodating. I would stay here again if I'm staying in Tokyo for sightseeing, etc.

We booked a room at this hotel for only a 24 hr stay, the room was ready when we got there. It's def not a luxury hotel, but we booked on a budget so it's more then we expected. Rooms were tiny. Very tiny. But clean. Hotel location is great. Not too hard to find by subway. (Hatagaya station is very close) the staff was very friendly and accommodating. A man who worked the front desk who went by the name (Honda) was great. Very friendly and and spoke perfect English with an Australian accent, which we loved! He was also very knowledgable and gave us good directions and tips for our sight seeing. Overall a great stay!

The moment I stepped in for my check-in, the guy at the counter was very helpful and friendly. The atmosphere felt very relaxed and was reminiscent of my college days at the dorm---people minding their own business as they ate the hotel's food and read books at the tables by the front lobby.

Have stayed here several times. Location suits me very well. 2 stop, 120 yen from Shinjuku and Yamanote Line, where Japan Rail Pass is valid. 6 min walk at Shinjuku for transfer. Always good ambience at hotel, professional staff and guests from all over the world. Also locals visit the Internett-cafè in the lobby. 200 steps from Hatagaya Station entrance. Post office with international ATM next to the hotel. 24-hour Gourmet City (very good food-store) 3 min away from hotel. FamilyMart foodstore and vending mashines 1 min from hotel. Why not 5 stars rating of rooms? The size. Two persons is a challenge. It is possible to put away a suitcase under the bed, this is helpful.

I personally enjoyed my stay here think the staff are some of the best and friendliest people I have met in my travels. I have come here twice and if I travel back to Tokyo will stay again. The staff is probably the best part of the hotel. The one guy I think his name was "Nao" was very friendly and helped me a lot with any questions I asked him.

I adored this hotel and would certainly use it again. The location was quite good, with many restaurants and eateries nearby. It also had a lovely bookshop for me to pick up some Japanese books, along with a street lined with cherry blossom trees. The station is a three-minute walk away, which will take you straight to Shinjuku Station (this is the main station and on the Yamanote line, from here you can go anywhere). So I found I was able to easily go to most tourist destinations. The staff were lovely! They were multi-lingual, with at least seven or eight languages being spoken in total by the various staff members, and they would willingly help out with any problem or question. They also would make conversation in a friendly manner, and one time - when the maids were cleaning my room, and I had an arm full of perishables - let me use their fridge. There is nothing they won't do to help you!There are computers for rent and free wi-fi. You can use your own computer for free.The cafe is spotlessly clean, with a huge amount of food to choose from. There is food from all over the country and the world, with the ability to suggest your own recipes for them to use. It is cheap and even the locals use the cafe often, so you are able to make many new friends and practise your Japanese skills with the locals. It is bright, airy, and colourful. The cleanliness is perfect. The maids clean every day without fail and spend vast amounts of time on every room, meaning not one speck of dust is left standing. They are also very friendly, all of which - despite not having good English - will smile and try to greet you. It's very secure. There are cameras on every floor, which are monitored by the staff in the reception, and keys are handed into reception before leaving (so no risk of losing keys or people making copies). Only registered guests are allowed into rooms, too. I would recommend this hotel to everyone. ありがとうござます、サクラホテル！あなたのホテルはとてもじょうずです！

Staying at SHH has been good value for money. Clean rooms, decent location and usually quiet. The staff is very helpful and patient. Naoto in particular was kind enought to assist me with some IT issues. Could not ask for more! Thanks guys!

My boyfriend and I stayed here for five nights. When we were choosing a place to stay for our trip, we didn't want a pricy hotel and we didn't want a hostel either. The Sakura Hotel Hatagaya was the PERFECT fit. While the rooms might be considered small, this encourages guests to get out of bed and explore the city.It really is more than just a place to sleep, as they foster a sense of community amongst all the guests, and all the staff members are BEYOND helpful and friendly. While the hotel is not central, it is literally a couple steps away from the Hatagaya station, which is only two quick stops away from Shinjuku--allowing us to travel anywhere in the city. Yes, the rooms are cozy, but for the price, they are absolutely perfect. I could not recommend this hotel more. Though we stayed less than a week, the Sakura Hotel Hatagaya felt like home after a couple of days. Each room has a great AC system and a small fridge to put your leftovers/waters inside.For example, we wanted to check out the nightlife scene in Tokyo. We approached the concierge asking for advice on where to go, when to go, and what to wear. From his past experience in the city, and great English, we got all the answers we were looking for. The concierge provide us with a map, directions for transit, and the appropriate dress code for the club (AgeHa--highly recommend). The 24 hour internet cafe has a fridge full of beer and assorted drinks. There is also a post office, and 24 hour "7/11" across the street (Family Mart). While we did not eat breakfast at the hotel, there are many food options in walking distance--no complaints. WE LOVED IT HERE! Can't wait to come back :)

If you are looking for a cheap and clean,quiet hotel in Tokyo,i believe Sakura Hotel Hatagaya is one of best choices.We had a pleasant stay last month.We paid 70 US$/night for a tiny clean double room.We appreciate friendly and helpful staffs.They speak good English.Thank you for a nice stay.We will come back.

The room was always clean, the building was usually quiet at night, the staff were friendly and helpful, and it is only two quick stops away from Shinjuku. I really could not ask for more out, especially with the low nightly cost. It really helped make my first visit to Japan great.

The hotel is practically on top of a subway stop, a must in Tokyo (although that stop isn't exactly central). For a reasonable price, I got a comfortably sized private room and bathroom (which is my only travelling requirement). There's a cafe in the lobby that has good, reasonably priced food if you're looking to try 'world cuisine'. But what really sells the hotel is the service. Every staff member I met was incredibly polite and friendly, willing to spend half an hour recommending the perfect ramen to order. I was there during a hotel-wide cooking class, and as I had a couple of hours free, I opted to participate. It was so much fun, meeting other travellers from around the world, as well as getting to know the staff better.Overall: good location, great value for the money, and fantastic staff. I will definitely be staying here in the future.

I've stayed at Sakura Hotel Hatagaya a number of times, and I've always enjoyed the community atmosphere. They give you a friendly, back-packer's style stay but with the comfort of private room. Usually I'm there for a night or two, although I did stay for five nights one week when leaving Japan after a job ended. This time I was with my wife for an overnight stay before our flight out the next afternoon.Sakura Hotel Hatagaya has the typical smallish rooms of a Tokyo business hotel, and the bathrooms are a bit cramped, especially the shower. We had a double corner room with a somewhat inconvenient column in the center we had to work around. On the other hand, the room itself was very clean, the bed quite comfortable and the hall very quiet and peaceful. I believe they've put down new carpet and refinished the walls since my last stay in May of 2012. We couldn't ask for a better experience with the desk and cleaning staff. Very friendly people and helpful.If you're expecting something upscale, you're in the wrong place. Young groups, solo travelers and couples who want to ramble around Tokyo will probably have the best experience. Sakura Hotel aims to give you a pleasant base for exploring and socializing with other travelers at a wallet-friendly price and they do excel at that. While we were just there for the night, if you're really into meeting people you can hang out in the cafe downstairs and take part in all kinds of fun events. I'm not sure if they were having anything that particular weeknd, but I have been there for a musical performance and the Sakura hotels have seasonal parties as well. The Hatagaya location is just two stops from Shinjuku and from there you're linked into all the fun locations of high-energy Tokyo. Plus the neighborhood itself features plenty of cheap eating places.

I went there only for my last two days in Tokyo. The location of the hotel is very convenient, just a minute walk to the hotel (I walk faster usually). If you are expecting a great hotel, you might be dissapointed, but with such a rasonable price, I'm glad that I can have a single room witch is pretty clean and neat, also with a BATHROOM, for people who don't used to using share bathroom/shower room, here is a good choice.The only few things I don't feel good about are...There's no view from the window, I can see someone else's apartment right in front of the window, I mean like really close, close enough that made me close the curtain all the time. Also, the cafe on the first floor accept cash only.Sakura Hotel Hatagaya:1. Very near Hatagaya Station, but you have to go to Shinjuku Station no matter where you wanna go.2.Wifi3. Room is small, but clean, neat, and comfortable. (Single room:An own bathroom, small TV, desk, small refridge.4. Vending Machine & laundry on 5F5. Cafe on the 1st floor, 350 yen for breakfast.(cash only)6. Family Mart and a Cosmeceutical shops near by.7. Ramen, chinese food, Mos Burger...etc. near by, too.8. Reasonable price and you can have no.1~7.9. Everything Staff can well communicate in English, that helps a lots.10. Standard Tokyo small hotel.

I stayed in a double room with my girlfriend, and the hotel was just fine. The rooms were a little small, however.Unless you are keen on staying close to Shinjuku, I'd say stay at their Ikebukuro location, which is more central since Hatagaya is 2 stops on a non-JR-line from Shinjuku.Overall, it was a very adequate, but pretty average experience.

This was actually my second time here at Sakura hotel Hatagaya. The first time was last year's April for a week with my mom. Last time I was in a Double room(with a semidouble bed). This time I'm in a single room (I think it's also a semidouble bed). The main reason why I chose to stay here was the location and price. It's a few minutes walk from subway station (2 station away from shinjuku). It's located in a neighbourhood-ish area, so there're convenience stores, supermarket, drug store, ramen shop etc. There's Mcdonalds and Mos Burger(Japanese burger chain). There's a bento shop. The best one must be Douter coffee shop where I went for breakfast (or rather brunch everyday). Lots of food places around. You should also try to walk across the street from the subway station; also a lot of food places.Room-wise, It's okay. The nescessities are there. No fancy Japanese toilet with lots of buttons though. Shampoo is provided. Things to note is that there's not much of a view for you and for some rooms the windows give you straight view into a neighbour's house which is pretty uncomfortable when it's spring and you want to let the sun in but you're seeing a stranger doing their thing in their own house. The room is not too small for me but for 2 person stay, it might feel a little cramped.There's a vending machine onsite but the convenience store is across the street so I recommend you to go there. There's also a washing machine (not free) but the recommended use time was 10am-8pm in order to not disturb other guests, so I didn't get to use it.If you buy food from outside to eat you can ask the staffs to heat them (in the microwave) for you. I have not once eat the hotel food so I have no clue how good/bad it is. There's wifi at the lobby. I'm not sure if it's hotel-wide already.They also provide baggage sending to airports/other hotels via Yamato transport but you need to send them 2 day earlier (e.g. you want them Sunday at the airport, you need to send them off on Friday) So I resort to the post office(JPpost) in front of the hotel. It only takes 1 day to deliver but it'll be a bit of a struggle cuz they don't really speak English.

Had 4 nights at Sukura and found hotel had all the basic requirements. Although found room to be so cold as had a corner room with draughty windows. Had to set air on every time the cleaners had been in to get he room cosy again. We eat breakfast daily at the hotel which was ok for the price.It is close to the metro so getting around was great. Staff were helpful.I would stay again :-)

Had three nights in Tokyo. Wanted to be relatively close to Shinjuku and Shibuya. Didn't want to spend a ton on hotel accommodations. Typically I stay in dorm-style hostels for as little money as possible; sometimes sharing a room full of bunks (which usually smells like a nasty locker room) and a communal bathroom with up to 20 people. I didn't see that that was an option when I was looking at this place online, so I spent a little more than I normally would and opted for a single room just for myself, with my own private bathroom. Have to say, it was really nice and wasn't that much more expensive. The room of course was cozy, but fine with me. It served my purpose. Most importantly, the room and the place in general was clean and comfortable. The staff was friendly and helpful, the fact that there's a cafe right in the lobby with food and drinks available round the clock was great. The location was easy enough to get to; short walk to the Hatagaya Station, which itself is only two stops from Shinjuku Station, which is only a few stops from Shibuya Station. There's a bunch of restaurants and convenience stores right near the hotel too, so you shouldn't be wanting for anything. (FYI, if you're out in Shibuya after the trains stop running, it's roughly a Y2000 cab ride back to this hotel).

My brother and I stayed in Sakura Hotel for 5 nights and were impressed with the cleanliness and comfortable atmosphere that the hotel presents. its good place to get value for your money. The staff were excellent and were extremely helpful no matter what it was. Most of them spoke reasonably good English too. They were kind enough to allow us to leave a bag there and pick it up on our way back to the airport for we got a bit too enthusiastic with shopping despite having a week left of traveling to do. The location was great being only a 1 minute walk from Hatagaya station and 2 stops from Shinjuku it made getting around Tokyo easy. the breakfast which the menu sought of exaggerates but its basically all you can eat toast or bread with coffee, tea and juice. There was also some broth or soup for japanese style breakfast. For us this was fine and it isnt bad for 350 yen each.

Rooms are clean and in excellent condition! There's an extremely helpful receptionist at the counter (his name is Nao) and he was real patient about everything. Friendly guests and staff, on top of it being situated in a spot close to shinjuku, make it absolutely reasonable to come back for a stay here again if I'm back in Tokyo.

This is the second Sakura hotel 'Ive stayed at now, the first being in Ikebukuru. Again they have delivered the goods with good value accommodation and fantastic friendly helpful staff, especially Nao who went out of his way to help me source a travel adapter. Only 2 subway stations and 3 minutes to Shinjuku, Hatagaya is a great little suburb close enough to the bright lights when you want to get amongst it but far enough away when it comes time to get some sleep.

I've stayed 2 nights in Sakura Hotel Hatagaya and feel so comfortable with the room and facilities. In 8 days trip, this hotel is the most comfy hotel. Me and my husband could sleep well & the room is clean. Though a little bit small for us, but since we didn't bring many luggage so it was okay. The location is near from Hatagaya Subway station, but maybe for tourist who is already had JR Pass need spend more cost to travel around Tokyo. If I come back to travel around Tokyo again for 2-5 days, I will check-in in Sakura Hotel Hatagaya again. :)

Similar to the title above, this hotel room was the smallest and the coldest room compared to the other hotels that we have visited on our family holiday on December 2012. Me, my wife, our 7 y/o son, and 2 y/o baby girl, with 2 large and 2 medium suitcases .. and a baby stroller and bags of groceries and souvenirs .. hmm .. it has also led me to be more creative :D Put 2 medium suitcases under the queen sized bed. Slightly shift the shoes rack, wardrobe, and TV table so there is enough space to put one large suitcase on the top of shoes rack, and one more large suitcase on the TV table .. of course we change the TV position and other appliances. When we are eating together in the room or when we preparing our self to go out, the single bed must be in stand position. And when we are sleeping, we were hugging each other in the blanket, warming each other .. (for Hotel Management: What happened to the windows and door sealant?) Nevertheless these circumstances make our family more chummy-er :)Compared with other hotels, The Sakura Hotel Hatagaya is the most favorite for our 7 y/o son. He was very impressed by the call bell on your reception desk (the one like a bird pecking) and the picture of our family hanging in the hotel wall. Because of that love of my son to this hotel, the hotel is also be our favorite .. .. The warm and friendly staff that welcome us and also very helpful - with a fluent English .. The location that close to everywhere (station, convenient store, coin laundry, various restaurant) .. The cleanliness .. Very trustworthy hotel staff .. So overall, we can say that we would come back and stay in Sakura Hotel Hatagaya again, next time when we visit Tokyo. Thankyou Sakura Hatagaya :))

Basically, the hotel is clean but the room is extremely small for us who has two big luggages. I practically have to squeeze myself around the room. The basic utilities are there with the hair dryer and TV. Computers available at the lobby will have to be paid 100 yen for 30 mins which I find a bit steep for a hostel and the person in charge does not seem to know much about the condition of other parts of nearby Tokyo area or even a good restaurant to eat. The person in charge does not even know how to operate the paid phone which is available at their hotel as the instructions given at the phone was quite difficult you understand at first. The shop around there selling food are has many choices like mos burger and cafe and even have a 24 hour bento shop. I booked 3 nights and was given special rate of 7200 yen per night for a double bed. Original price was 9000 yen. For 9000 yen room and not really at the heart of Shinjuku and have to change train from the main JR line. I really think that this place is overated and I will not stay there for a second time.

The problem we had here was purely the location. Altho there was a subway just 2 min walk fr hotel, but the subway station wasnt in the main line. But if u dont mind changing station frequently, then this place is alright. The rooms are small but comfortable. I liked the cafe which was open 24 hours. In terms of value, well everything in japan is expensive so, i guess the price is something which we cant complain that much about.

I visited this hotel last year and it is well allocated, very close to Hatagaya station. The rooms are very small, but that is normal in Japan, specially in Tokyo. What I did not like about this hotel was that the cleaning staff was knocking at the door rather early in the morning, when we were sleeping and that was pretty uncomfortable. The other people in the staff were pretty friendly, and I had a good time in this hotel.

I was in Tokyo end Mar for a business trip and decided to extend 1 day personal stay and I picked to stay in Sakura.For the price of US$76 a nite booked through Agoda, the hotel is affordable in a prime location near a Hatagaya Station via the Keio New Line from Shinjuku Station (2 stations away) and with free wifi.Within close proximity, there is a Family mart, MOS burger, a cafe, bakery shop, etc.Pros : affordable room for a night stay in the big city of Tokyo with free wifiCons : the quality of sleep is average with thin wall and you could hear water running in the pipe.

A friend of mine recommended this hotel for our first trip to Japan and we couldn't have been happier. The room was small yes but once you figure out how to arrange your belongings, it wasn't that bad. The staff was great, very helpful, spoke very good English. It was a quick walk from Hatagaya station which was a very great location.

The hotel is a long way out so lots of train travel. The rooms are very small and nothing like the pics on their website. Worst of all the cavitation keeps you awake at night. The sound of water running through the pipes ecco's through the whole hotel and wakes you up. We had very limited sleep and I would never stay there again.

I stayed one week in Tokyo, and the hotel was very clean, the staff are very friendly, the room was clean, it´s just 2 blocks away from the Hatagaya Subway station, and it´s very closer to Shinjuku, if you want to take a taxi from Shinjuku station only takes 10 minutes, I hope to come back soon.

Stayed at Sakura again for the second time in Tokyo.Small rooms but you are in Tokyo and it is cheap.Rooms serviced daily and they offer a very basic breakfast (one to be missed)100 meters to the subway and you pass a number of inexpensive resturants including the francise "Donutor" which does a breakfast set (Choise of 6) for about A$6 with great coffee.The hotel is good enough with great front of desk staff who can direct you anywhere.

Being Norwegian, having travelled in Japan for one week with a different accomodation every night, it felt very relaxing to arrive Sakura Hotel Hatagaya. Kind of a "mid-between" japanese and International hotel. Staff was strictly correct in accordance to Japanese custom, and at the same time open minded and active asking their guests for further connection, like personal history and invitation to share recies from ones homeland. This approoach of course also makes a good and friendly atmosphere among the guest, who often use the cafè for a drink, a meal or to work on papers or computers. from the hotel there is 160 steps to the local station Hatagaya. Train from Hatagaya to Shinjuku, the worlds largest traffic hub, takes 4 min. But surprisingly, the areas next to the hotel seems like nice residential areas. The most amazing and beautyful food stores I saw on my Japan round-about are located five minute walk from the hotel.

Stayed in Tokyo (ginza) same time last year. This year decided to try Some place closer to Shinjuku. Have only been here a day, but already am very happy with the hotel and the location. The hotel is cheap, clean, has friendly staff and is close to all amenities (especially restaurants). It's close to Shinjuku, shibuyu and Harajuku.

Sakura Hotel Hatagaya was the third hotel in our eleven day trip in Japan. Even the Sakura Hotel room was the smallest and the coldest room (what happened to the windows and door sealer?) compare to other two hotel, but my 7 yrs son loved The Sakura Hotel Hatagaya, more than the other two. My son was very impressed of the call bell in your reception desk (the one like a bird pecking) and the picture of our family hanging in the hotel wall.We were very please to stay at this hotel because our the warm and friendly staff that welcome us and also very helpful - and with fluent English too..Other than that, Sakura Hotel Hatagaya location is close to everywhere (station, convenient store, coin laundry, various restaurant), just by 5 min walking...Overall, we can say that we would come back and stay in Sakura Hotel Hatagaya again, next time we visit Tokyo.

This hotel was recommended to me by a friend that had stayed there several times before so I thought I'd give it a go. I spent about 10 days at this great little hotel when I visited Japan and even though I went off to visit other places, I came back to stay there when I was in Tokyo. The rooms are small but they are clean and met my basic needs as I was out and about most of the time. It is located very close to public transport and lots of great little shops, bars and restaurants. The staff at the hotel are fabulous and really made my stay so much better. They were friendly and knowledgeable and went out of their way to help, especially Naoto, as he helped me sort out some travel arrangements. Thanks too to Sariko and Ai, lots of good advice on where to go and what to see and where to eat etc. All the staff seemed well traveled and understood the needs of visitors. I would stay there again. You guys are great. Cheers.

Sakura Hotel is nothing fancy, but it is a great hotel for the budget traveler! I've seen some reviews where people complain about the entra train transfer but honestly, it's only a 15-20 minute walk to Shinjuku and you basically walk in a straight line! I did it almost everyday! You're there to sightsee! Which brings me to my next point: yes, the rooms are small! Why does this matter? Get out! Go do something! You should only be sleeping here! If you're coming to Tokyo solely to sit in your pretty hotel room, suck it up and spend a few hundred for a fancy room. I found the rooms to be very cozy and clean. The bed was comfortable and the area is insanely quiet. You will definitely sleep well! However, the walls do seem to be quite thin as I could hear the people in the next room talking and I could also hear when they coughed, but no one was trying to be loud by any means and I never heard anything during the night (just a bit in the mornings). The shower pressure was great and the water always nice and hot. Maybe I was lucky since I did not experience any weird smell that other reviewers have mentioned.The cafe in the lobby is nice. I didn't eat their often but what I did have was decent. Usually I just sat there to use the free wifi, which works fine. The staff are very friendly and speak very good English. When I needed change for the trains they had no problem exchanging my bills for me. When I wasn't sure how to get where I was going, they gave me booklets, maps, and written directions complete with what the fare would cost to get there. Overall I would 100% stay here again! This will actually be my first choice for my next trip considering the excellent price and awesome experience I had. Honestly, it just felt more homey than the 'nicer' hotels I stayed in during my trip.

If you're looking for a well priced place to crash in Tokyo, then this is the place for you! The rooms are tiny, but if you need more than just a bed and bathroom, go to a fancy hotel. This place is great for the budget traveller, who is spending more time out and about than at the hotel. The rooms were clean, the staff friendly, breakfast simple but cheap, and all you can eat. Definitely a good location to base yourself in to see Tokyo on a budget!

The location was good, the staff was very helpful and friendly (and spoke English well), the rooms were tiny but very clean. I wish that we had spent our whole stay here, and not only the first 6 nights. This is the only hotel/hostel out of the three that we stayed in that I would return to.

First place i stayed at in Japan. The service was good, staff were friendly. Free breakfasts are always good. The bed was super comfy and the first morning i woke up there i looked out the window and saw my first cherry blossom tree. I have reason to believe this is a 'love hotel' but none the less. It was clean and made a good impression on me. I would go back.
My main complaint was the bed being so uncomfortable. It was super convenient and a great price.

I typed 'cheap hotel tokyo' and this hotel came up on Google. I went on Japanese discount hotel website but this hotel was actually cheaper than any other ! The photo looks pretty okay and 350yen breakfast seemed great as well.It was my first time staying at the 'Business hotel' in Japan. I heard about how small and simple the normal 'business hotel' are, so I was a bit worried...Arrived at Tokyo station by 'Sinkansen'. Changed the train to 'Chuo- sen'(I'm Japanese but I was already lost there..), went to Shinjyuku, had to change the train there to 'Keio-sin sen', which felt soooo faaaarrrr away from JR train line exit with 2 massive suit cases and backpacks... and later found out that its only 1500yen to catch TAXI from Shinjyuku from Sakura hotel lolOnce you know the 'Keio-sin sen' entrance, its only 2 stops from Shinjyuku.The hotel is surrounded by so many good shops!(restaurants, convenience store, chemist, cafe..etc)Staff in the hotel were very polite. went to our room, so scared of looking inside..YES the room is tiny tiny tiny!!!extremely tiny!!! probably smaller than my bed room in Australia. Only 1 doble bed and thin bed side table fits. Luckily we had soft suit case, so suit case fit nicely(but just!!)But it was actually really comfortable!We weren't planing to spend our precious time in Japan in the hotel anyway.and we loved just sitting on the bed, drinking beer that we got from 24 hours convenience store which is 1 min away from hotel, and watching Japanese TV at night.And the size of the room is just usual thing for 'Business Hotel'. That's why its business hotel and that's why its cheap.350yen breakfast is cheap but not worth it.You can get out from the hotel and go to convenience store or 5 mins walk and there is a fresh bakery. anyway I stayed there for 5days and at the end, Sakura hotel was our home in Tokyo.It was really comfortable.I certainly recommend this hotel if you want to stay in the convenience location to travel Tokyo.

It was actually my first time staying in a budget hotel on my 5th trip to Tokyo, this time bringing 2 of my friends. We wanted to be in a close location within Shinjuku, Harajuku and Shibuya. Shinjuku station is a nightmare to carry suitcases around while trying to find the train that takes you to Hatagaya.Sakura Hotel Hatagaya is in such a nice area. We were surprised it was actually pretty quite at night. The staff were nice and our room was a twin for 3. The room was small with the two beds pushed together but it was still good. Had our own private bathroom which was clean, mini fridge, tv and a cable line for the internet. Wireless was only available downstairs. There were drink vending machines on each floor, and one of the floors hand coin operated washing machines.There is a cafe downstairs selling a variety of world foods and drinks available on their menu. A bit pricey but good. Plenty of seats, a piano, magazines, books, guitars, tv, lounge and computers to use. There were plenty of places to eat around, conbini, drug store, mos burger, coffee place, karaoke, book store, bento store all in a minute or two walking distance. Train station just nearby.The only complaint I would have is when my friend walked me into the hotel and we were saying our goodbyes when a male staff member rudely said out loud to my friend that they were not allowed up to my room which embarrassed me so much! Never in my life has any hotel staff in the world have said this to me. One of the rules is that only the people who signed into the room and paid are allowed, but I was not inviting them up which I found rude. I think there are better places to stay for 13,000 a night than here but it is a good location.There was a free breakfast. Nothing too fancy. Toast, selection of drinks, soups and rice.

I selected this hotel because it was near the site of a conference I was intending and really wasn't so concerned about the expense involved. I selected a room with a double bed because I thought it would be a bit roomier, but it turned out to be just the opposite -- part of what might have been floor space was taken up by the wider bed!I was surprised to find that the clientele was almost exclusively non-Japanese, so if you don't speak Japanese and are looking for inexpensive lodging this might suit you well. Business hotels in Japan normally serve a free breakfast. The one at the Sakura was disappointing. There was only a choice of two types of bread, with strawberry jam or marmalade to top it along with Miso soup. There was only one toaster oven, so when crowded you would have to eat your bread cold. No "onigiri" (rice balls) or other forms of rice were present and nothing that contained protein -- no eggs, ham, dried fish or some of the other items often served at a business hotel breakfast. They did serve decent coffee as well as one type of fruit juice -- orange one day, pineapple the next. There was, however, a "FamilyMart" convenience store on the corner where you could pick up a wider variety of breakfast items rather inexpensively.The toilet was the typical low-end prefab type --cramped but with the basics. A warning says to keep the door shut while showering, lest the steam set off the fire alarm.The bed was comfortable although I found the tick-tock of the alarm clock a little distracting.The hotel is two stops from Shinjuku on the Keio new line (underground) and about a block from the station.

Stayed here for 2 nights in a double room. It's conveniently located near the Hatagaya train station but the rooms are extremely tiny. Have stayed in other Tokyo hotels before but this one was way smaller than what I was expecting. There is basically no space to walk/move in the room after we placed both our luggage at the corridor. It was value for money for me as I had a discount after booking this on the internet; however, I might not stay here again as the rooms are way too tiny. If you travel as a couple and want to stay here, you may want to consider booking the Corner Double or Superior Double rooms.

I stayed here by myself for 4 days en route to New Zealand. I thought that for Tokyo it was very well priced & I had a really nice stay here. I was nervous that the room would be literally a closet size but was pleasantly surprised. Although a small room, there was ample space for me & my suitcase plus a desk. It was very clean and the shower had great water pressure! Breakfast included was an extra benefit... And good coffee too. The staff were very helpful and friendly. The one negative thing I would say is that the room had obviously been smoked in previously & as there wasn't a big window so you could smell it still. Overall though I thought this was excellent value for money (especially for someone travelling alone & on a budget in an expensive city) and would definitely stay there again.

We stayed at Sakura Hotel Hatagaya for a total of six nights, and it was absolutely brilliant. The rooms were clean and comfortable and excellent value for money (yes, they are small, but big enough for you to leave your things and comfortably get read, and this shouldn't be a surprise as it does clearly specify this on their website). Breakfast was also included in this exceptionally low price, and was lovely and filling!The staff were excellent - they went out of their way to make us feel welcome, and even made us pizza in their excellent 24 hour cafe in the small hours after we stumbled home from a night in Roppongi!! They were also very accommodating when we arrived late due to a delayed flight from Beijing.It is right next to Hatagaya station, as well as handily placed next to an AM/PM convenience store, bakery, post office (with ATM that accepts British / European debit cards- and I guess probably American/Canadian/Australian etc - this is quite rare in Japan). This leaves you only 3 minutes from Shinjuku, which is a birlliant place to explore and also the place to connect to the JR Yamanote line (the only way to see Tokyo!!!)I cannot speak highly enough of this hotel - whether you are young, old, couples, families or groups of friends, I cannot imagine you will find a better, friendlier budget option in Tokyo.

Although expecting Sakura Hotel to be run as a backpackers hotel my partner and I were not expecting much but were still very disappointed. The check in time was 2pm in the afternoon, and to leave our bags there whilst killing time everyones luggage was just left in the main lobby piled all around the desk. As recieving our key we had to sign an agreement to hand in the room key to front desk every time we leave the hotel. This was uncomfortable and I thought not needed as it was a nuisance having to put everthing back into your suitcase to lock as not wanting anything to go missing. Paying the extra amount to be upgraded to a corner room for extra space we were disappointed as to entering the room a huge concrete pole being in the middle of the room, which we could not get our luggage past without a hassle. The room was generally clean except for the stains all over the lounge and carpet which were grotty. Would not recommend, and know ou can find alot better hotels for the same price.

great hotel in tokyo at a great pricewas a little difficult to find from the station when we arrived at night, but didnt take too longhighlight here was the helpful and friendly staff, which was great since it was our first place we stayed in Japan. Spoke english very well too.Rooms were small, as i expected, but who cares when your out sightseeing all day and night anyway!

I found this place through the reviews on trip advisor and was VERY pleased when I arrived. Its 2 stops from Shibuya, but outside from all the crazyness of the city, so you can have some peace of mind when you sleep. The places is great for sleeping, not to lounge in the hotel because the rooms are small, but your in tokyo to enjoy it not to stay in your room!The staff speaks good english and are very helpful to make RVSPs for you if you need it. The lobby cafe has free WIFI, and foreign beers!And again ITS A GREAT LOCATION, CHEAP and close to everything ^o^!

We stayed at the Sakura Hotel Hatagaya for 4 nights when we arrived to Tokyo. The hotel is conveniently located, 2 minutes away from the Hatagaya subway station which is 2 stops away from Shinjuku and the main subway lines.The hotel itself is very basic but clean. The rooms are tiny and difficult to live in when you're two, but still it does the job. Choose the Sakura Hatagaya as a basis to explore Tokyo, leave in the morning and come back to sleep.

Well located close from the Hatagaya subway station, the rooms are quite cheap (for Tokyo) but very tiny: there is no other space available for the luggage than the small corridor between the bathroom and the bed (so that you have to climb over to reach one or the other). This hotel is ok if you are on a budget and are not too claustrophobic, but I am pretty sure that something better can be found for the same price.

If you're looking for a budget place where you can sleep, shower and store your belongings, this is a good choice. Staff was friendly and helpful. If you are a non-smoker be sure to request a non-smoking room because the smoking rooms smell like smoke. Just a five minute walk to the train station to get a connection to all major stations.

we upgraded to a larger twin room, after staying one night in a double room. The room was tiny, even though we had expected it to be small, this one was really really small and felt quite stale. The bathroom was tiny, and also had a bad smell associated to it. Size wise the room might have been fine for one person, but we found it quite uncomfortable. We managed to fit our packs under the bed, if we had different luggage we've no idea where we would have stored it!! The bed was squished right up under the window (which had a view of a stairwell.. ) and in the morning my clothes actually felt damp from being left on the small stool overnight. We had attempted to use the air condition/heater but turned it off as it seemed to emit an awful awful smell, and was covered in dust.The second day we upgraded to a twin room and were so much happier with this one! It seemed to be at least TWICE the size of the first room (was located on a higher floor) was bright and spacious and had a wonderful street view! The difference astounded us!This second room was quite lovely to stay in, and really nice to come back to after a day out. I should say the cleaning staff were a bit... abrupt, noisy and a little intense!!The staff were hit and miss. We had a lovely member of staff help us find a local vegetarian restaurant, and she was really sweet in assisting us, and on the other hand we had staff members who seemed distant, and appeared as if they didn't want to be there. We also had a mix up in the 'cafe' part of the 'hotel'. I had wanted to order a meal and asked if it were vegetarian.. (and this seems to be an issue throughout japan.. not just in this hotel) and was given yes yes vegetables and noodles as an answer so went ahead and ordered. From experience I decided to just check again there was no meat in this dish... and listed all the things I wanted to avoid - beef-chicken-pork-fish.. (etc etc.) The staff member replied that there was a little bit of pork and I could just seperate it from the vegetables.... needless to say I changed my order, oh and by the way.. the food on the menu appears to be pre cooked and simply reheated and wasn't terribly palatable..... So... would we stay there again? If we wanted to go back to that area.. and it was convenient.. we would definately request the TWIN room at least, and not having high expectations would probably enjoy it.

Technically this is not a hotel, it is more of a hostel.Everything is of basic and budget.
