The room is extremely small, there is no extra space for your large luggage, which must be placed in the corridor inside the room. There is no space for you to air out your clothes, you have to air out your clothes by putting them on top of the pull-out handles of your luggage. There is no space for a study chair, if you must use their free net, you have to sit on the bed. The toilet is also very small to the point that the basin tap doubles as the shower tap. Everything about this hotel/hostel is reminiscent of the 90s, i.e. 20 years ago without any form of significant upgrade. Decor, furniture, bed-head, toilet, carpet, building structure, overall design. If you are a backpacker or looking for a roof over your head with a budget of 9,000 yen a night, this hotel/hostel is perfect for you. Afterall, it is located in Hatagaya, which is a throw away from Shinjuku which means the hotel/hostel is quiet yet geographically convenient (it is also 5 mins walk from Hatagaya station).

the rooms are small, and the furniture/blankets seem to be old, but clean. the staff is friendly and speaks English. They can give you good advices on things to do. The breakfast is good, but simple. The atmosphere was really nice, more like in a hostel, where you can easily meet people. It is not too far away from Shibuya (by metro), but the Tokio metro system can be very confusing. The area is nice and quiet with some restaurants near by. We really enjoyed our stay and would probably come again.

The Hotel is conveniently located, not far from the subway stop and Shinjuku. The room is rather small but beds are comfortable. The tiny bathroom had a bad smell that wouldn't go away. The carpet has seen better days. Nice little continental breakfast included in the price. The price is good for Tokyo and we would have been satisfied had it not been for the smell in the bathroom.

We stayed for 3 nights and chose the hotel based on price and location. Both were fine - changing onto the Keio new line is fairly easy once you've done it once, and it was only a problem when we came back late at night (after midnight) and had to wait about 15 mins for the train - it would have been nice to be able to just walk out of shinjuku station. Also Hatagaya isn't included in the 1000 a day travel pass as it's a privately owned line, so that's and extra 120 yen each time you get on. Not a biggie but just to point it out.although it says shibuya it's actually closer to shinjuku - which is a great area to visit and after 2 visits to tokyo one of my favourites.the hotel is clean, the staff are friendly, the area has nice places to eat which are better value than more central places in tokyo.main thing to point out is the rooms are TINY!!! i have never been in such a small room. i guess that's why the rooms are cheap. we couldn't both get ready in the morning at the same time - one had to go into the bathroom and the other get dressed. the decor of the hotel is not flash, the carpet is a bit worn, the walls starting to get scuffed, but it's not depressing or dirty.There's also a free breakkie (toast and jam) and a little cafe in reception with brochures and guides.i wouldn't pick this for a romantic trip, but fine for a couple who have travelled together before, or aren't too fussed.

This hotel is fine if you are on a budget and are staying for a few days. I stayed there for five nights and ...got used to it. I was out most of the time so it was ...ok. For the price, it is a "travel" hotel. I would stay there again.

I would definitely recommend sakura hotel and would return due to it's convenience and price. It's location makes it easy to get into the city while saving a substantial amount of money and being away from the hustle and bustle means that it is not noisy. I enjoyed the breakfast which consisted or white bread or wholemeal rolls as well as croissants - plain and chocolate and for the two days that we were there they had beef stock soup and minestrone the next day.

The Sakura Hotel Hatagaya is a very conveniently located hotel only 2 rail stops from Shinjuku. We enjoyed our stay there and the staff was very friendly and helpful. When I couldn't figure out how to turn on the TV, a desk clerk immediately came up to the room to help me. The maids are very considerate and, when we couldn't make it out of the room in time before they finished their duties, they left us a bag with our fresh towels in it.

The hotel is really inexpensive but very clean for the cost. Of course the room is small but it was perfect for just one person. The internet service was free too! The location is really convenient, it's really close to Shinjuku station so it's easy to get around. Since you're in a residential district it seems pretty quiet at night which is nice when you're exhausted after walking all over Tokyo. All of the staff speak at least a little English and they are really friendly. I fully recommend this hotel to anyone traveling to Tokyo on a budget.

Nive hotel. Small room with a small window from which you could see next building stairs(0.5meters). The dryer couldn´t dry the clother after using it for a long time. Near to Shinjuku, but using a new subway line, a lot of time to transfer to the other subway lines. Breakfast included in the room fare.

I booked this hotel for 3 night stay for my girlfriend and I. Our first time in Japan. Booked as part of a well known hotel chain and its reasonable price and proximity to underground (MRT). Room + shower very small (but maybe standard for Tokyo) for this price. Close to MRT BUT Hatagaya is not really an area you walk around at night - nothing much to see and do. Need to get MRT somewhere else. Maybe better to stay at Ueno area.

I really couldn't complain about this hotel... But if you're a little baby about where you stay, I could see some one not really liking it. All though the hotel is far from the Narita airport, its still pretty easy to get to. The directions on their web site were really helpful.Once we got there and checked in, my first thought when we got to the room was "dang! this is REALLY small!!"... Because it looks a lot bigger in all the pictures. You have just enough room to walk from one side to the other and turn around ha ha. The bed was a decent size though. The free internet is a LAN cable that they supply... it worked pretty good and the cable was long enough to lay in the bed and be on the computer at the same time. The only sort of bad part about the room was the bathroom... It was so small, that the sink and the bath tub shared a faucet... and the toilet wasn't one of those really popular ones in Japan, that squerts your butt. It also had a smell to it... sort of like that Nair hair removal foam... it wasn't THAT bad though. I think it's cheap enough to not really matter.They offer a free breakfast, but it wasn't the best free breakfast I have ever had... Really it's just toast, and weak coffee... but we ate it every day and it held us over till lunch.I would stay here again.
dark room with lots of stains on the worn-out floor rug...i prefer to stay as a backpacker, not a business person. the air conditioner made me feel sore throat.

a great simple hotel to stay at with close access to everything you could want to do in tokyo. the staff are polite and speak very good english. I will certainly be considering this place again when i return to tokyo. It can be a little hard to find, but if you get to shibuya station and catch a taxi it is only $20 AUD

Clean room and friendly staffs, who mostly can speak and understand english. I like it there because it is within the residential area, so that you can have a feel of a japanese neighborhood. It is very near to Hatagaya station. It is a good stroll in the evening from Hatagaya to Shinjuku. Especially after a good dinner in the various eateries in Hatagaya (along Koshu Kaido), which is about 2 - 5 mins walk from the Hatagaya Sakura. A recommended place for dinner will be yakitori joint, くし　こう, which is cosy and serve good yakitori (please refer to pictures). Try the grill wasabi chicken and fish. Dont forget about the beer. The place is operated by その だ みのろ さん (Mr Sono da) and his wife. The shop has been operating for 30+ years and was passed down from his parents. A stroll to Shinjuku will take approximately 20mins (4km in distance). It is straight down the main carriage way (Koshu Kaido) towards Shinjuku. Hence, no turning to make and you will not get lost.

Honestly, I was a little disappointed when I entered the hotel. But then again, you get what you pay for. This hotel seems more suited for a backpacker that might be sick of dorming with others. In fact, I believe the Sakura runs some other backpacker hostel-type places. The room itself smelled moldy when I entered. I had to turn on the air conditioning and open the windows to get rid of the smell, and even then, it did not go away. I also had to clean the air conditioning vents, as they were moldy and dusty. I would recommend a different hotel if you can spring a little bit extra

The hotel is pretty well located and easy to get to if you're looking to explore the Shinjuku/Shibuya/Roppongi side of town, which is why we stayed here during our 2nd stint in Tokyo. And although by international standards I've Perhaps it was unfortunate that they were the last hotel we stayed in during our 2.5 week trip (for 3 nights), however, given the standard we had been exposed to in other parts of Tokyo/other cities for similar / less pricing, we were disappointed by this hotel.By international standards, I've stayed in motels/small hotels that were less clean, but of all the hotels we stayed in Japan, this was the smallest and least well maintained. The airconditioner could not really be turned up, so we had to open the window (luckily it was cool outside).The bed we had was old. Toilet emitted an odour we couldn't get rid of.Front reception although friendly, were the least professional / acommodating of all hotels we had stayed in. Overall, an OK budget option, but its worth looking around as you can get better at similar pricing.If you're looking to explore other side of Tokyo or Tokyo central, especially if you have a JR pass, you may find you end up saving money by booking a slightly more expensive but much better hotel towards Kinshicho etc. Getting to Tokyo central/Akihabara/attractions on the other side seemed to take a LOT longer.Satisified by overall international standards perhaps, but by the high standards set by japanese hotels, we fell unsatisfied overall.

getting from narita to hattagaya is easy just follow the map given u'll be there within 90mins.getting around is easy as well just tat u'll need to get to shinjuku (5min),quiet surrounding away from busy tokyo but yet so near wat can u ask for for tis price,room is small if ur the type tat like staying in the room tats nt the place wifi only at lobby

If you want to stay in Tokyo for a few days and have only limited budget, this hotel may be a good choice. The room layout reminds me of a single room in a college dormitory. But it comes with many amenities and has a very compact bathroom. The room has a distinct odor which indicates the age of the hotel, but you can easily get used to it. Its location is superb, only a couple minutes walking to a subway station from which you can readily tap into the vast Tokyo mass transit system. The room rate even includes a simple breakfast and free internet (cable provided). The hotel staff is very helpful. The immediate hotel's neighborhood has many restaurants, banks, markets, convenient stores, book stores, and drug stores. There is even a post-office next door.

other than the slight annoyance of the location (you need to change to new keio line at shinjuku), the hotel was great. helpful staff was very proficient in english and helpful in suggesting local attractions and helping to find train schedules, baseball game schedules, etc. rooms are cozy and comfortable with all amenities, small but that is the norm. area is quiet at night, convenience stores 10 seconds away, nothing much else in the area though.

The hotel building itself is nothing amazing but the the staff were very friendly and organized a group of us to take part in a local festival which turned out to be the highlight of my holiday. Has a hostel vibe but hotel standard rooms with the age of guests seeming to average around 30. Highly recommended as a place to meet other people if you don't fancy slumming it in a hostel.

nice neighborhood location, check out local pub and bar in the area and just walk around. quite good atmosphere and staff are friendly, be sure to ask for a pass for free drink from their galleries all over Tokyo.

Stayed here for 5 nights and found it to be a great little hotel/hostel. Rooms are very small but you are never in them as Tokyo has so much to see! Breakfast was quite limited.....toast! And coffee/tea, but there is a bakery around the corner so we used to refuel there. Hairdryers in room, shower was always hot and powerful.Shijinku station is the main station and is a little walk away but can easily be reached by tube from Hatagaya station. It did take us a few days to get our head round the tube transport system and we did get lost a number of times but it was all part of the fun! Would definatly recomend going to Mount Fuji, a great day out with some amazing views!

Yes, Hatagaya is not a major station, and finding the Keio New line from Shinjuku took quite awhile, but once that is sorted out, I liked the convenience of the hotel from Hatagaya hotel.Do be aware that weekday mornings, the trains from Hatagaya to Shinjuku are madly crowded. be prepared to squeeze on the train, with no little beathing space! man and women alike, all squeeze!!Hotel was not hard to find, with their instructions on the website. Quite a few nice shops and restaurants along the way, and a very large convenience store, AM-PM. I like the friendliness of the staff, and all of them that I met (3 men, 2 women) speak good english. i had no problems with communicating with them, or even engaging in conversations of unlikely topics! I wanted to get my ears pierced in Japan, so I sought one of the staff's help on how to go about doing it in Tokyo. She was so kind as to tell me where to get the studs, and helped me to read out the instructions on the package (which were in Japanese), and finally, at my insistence and persuasion, helped me out in the DIY process as well! I am very happy as they do make me feel right a home, and they feel like friends to me.The room is undoubtedly small (but I guess it's the same everywhere else in Tokyo). Small to the extent that there is no place to open up my large samsonite luggage to access my things. In the end, it became a ritual every night to open up the luggage in the area just at the foot of the room door, and the opened luggage will reach the foot of the toilet door, which made moving around hard. Please take note for those having large luggages. you probably will have to perform the same routine as me.*Warning* please do not take a hot shower with the toilet door open! When I did it, it set off the smoke alarm in the room, and i apparently when i did that, I woke up alot of angry occupants in the bulding *oops*... the smoke detector is very sensitive to the steam coming from the toilet, so please be careful.Wired internet access in the room is free, but only if you bring your own computer. there are computers at the lobby for your use, but they cost money. so please bring your own laptop if possible.A4 printing is available at 30yen per page as well in the lobby.

Location:You would think that Hatagaya is a major station but it's not. You need to take Keio Line to reach Hatagaya and the frequency of trains is not very good (as compared to others in Tokyo).Hotel is just a walk away from the station, which is good.Check in: Staff just did not understand English, especially the night staff. We had such a tough time in making them understand that we just need a taxi in morning. Finally, we had to call Taxi ourselves.The check in time is 4 PM and Check out time is 10 AM. Wonder what they do in that 6 hour time frame cos the rooms aren't that big enough which would require ages to clean. Ok, this is not rare for Tokyo so this should not be counted as a problem. They promised us that our bags will be transferred to our rooms but when we came back at 11 PM, our bags were all over the lobby. This was not acceptable. Either you promise or you don't. Do not make false claims.Rooms: We booked a single and a double room. To my surprise, both the rooms were almost similar, except in the double room, they have managed to cramp in a sofa. Bed size is exactly same, wonder why they charged me seperate amounts for the same. Beds were comfy and liveable. Bathrooms (as per Tokyo's standards) are tiny but well furnished.I would recommed this hotel to only backpackers and no one else. People with children or heavy luggage, please avoid as they do not have any bell boy services or even a luggage trolley. I know this is a budget hotel but I have stayed in other budget hotels also and trust me, they were a lot better than this one. I have been told that other Sakura Hotels in Tokyo are much better off than this one.

Stayed in this property the first time i was in Tokyo. it's situated about 3 minutes from the Hatagaya subway station, just off Shinjuku. For a budget hotel this is actually quite good.The rooms were small but the beds were reasonably comfortable and bathroom... tiny (as usual.. for japan hotels).Breakfast was normal, toast and butter/jam with coffee/tea.If you are a backpacker with a little more budget to spare than a shared hostel, or if you are not intending to spend a lot of time lazing in a 5-stars hotel, but just to use it to sleep, this is actually a very pleasant hotel to stay. Oh, it's quiet too!
